Name: Durrazzo
Comments: Blue H Technologies BV ceased trading in October 2012.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 10 Oct 2012: Blue H Technologies cease trading.

Name: Star of the South
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 04 Sep 2018: According to the Australian Friends of the Earth organisation, the Star of the South has been  held up by the federal Coalition government for unknown reasons. The federal government is yet to sign off on an exploration license for the Star of the South, which would take it to the next stage of detailed ecological and economic analysis. The organisation has launched a petition in support of a request for a status update from the Energy Minister Angus Taylor.
Owners: Offshore Energy Pty Ltd,Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners
Developers: Offshore Energy Pty Ltd,Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners

Name: Global Renewable Solutions - Power Platform
Comments: The project is a hybrid wind-wave power concept with a total capacity of 9MW for each Power Platform. The platform will consist of one wind turbine (up to 7MW) and 6 (up to 1.5MW) oscillating water column (OWC) wave devices. The design is for six or more 'energy islands' to be put together in an array.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Apr 2017: Global Renewable Solutions intends testing the power platform, minus wind turbine, off of the coast of Co. Mayo. Ireland in the second quarter of 2017.
Owners: Global Renewable Solutions(formerly Marine Power Technologies Pty Ltd)
Developers: Global Renewable Solutions(formerly Marine Power Technologies Pty Ltd)

Name: Pirallahi Island
Comments: Project to be financed by oversea investment and to be built within an area of oil production.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Oct 2015: Project submitted to Cabinet of Ministers for consideration.

Name: Pirallahi-Chilov - Az?ralternativenerji
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 11 Nov 2018: Azeralternativenergy LLC under the State Agency for Alternative and Renewable Energy Sources is negotiating with foreign investors from the Middle East, China and Canada for financing a project in the Caspian Sea. The project will be located near Pirallahi settlement and Chilov island with a capacity of 200MW. The project would require the introduction of a 'green tariff'.

Name: Zira Island
Comments: The vision of Zira Island is to create an island that is entirely independent of external resources - a self contained island development. Developers plan to use the foundations of disused oil platforms to mount turbines.

Name: Chittagong - Givent DCL Green Energy
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Jan 2015: Wind turbine installation permission has been received from Chittagong Port Authority (CPA) and Civil Aviation Authority Bangladesh (CAAB), Head Quarters.
Developers: Givent DCL Green Energy,Deepwater Windenergy Investment AB
Foundation Comments: Marcon Wind Power AB design

Name: Chittagong
Comments: Bangladesh Power Development Board intends to select a potential sponsor to develop a 100-200MW offshore wind project on a build, own and operate basis.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 24 Aug 2010: Receipt of pre-qualification submissions.

Name: Large Scale Ocean Energy - Feasibility study
Comments: July 2018 - Barbados Government has issued a request for Expressions of interest to undertake a wide range of technical and environmental studies, as well as related capacity building activities, to investigate the feasibility and facilitate the construction of a large-scale Ocean Energy power plant or array in Barbados. Technologies which are to be considered are Ocean Thermal Energy Conversion (OTEC), fixed offshore wind, and floating offshore wind.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 25 Jul 2018: Deadline for submittal of Expressions of Interest - To undertake a wide range of technical and environmental studies, as well as related capacity building activities, to investigate the feasibility and facilitate the construction of a large-scale Ocean Energy power plant or array in Barbados. Technologies which are to be considered are Ocean Thermal Energy Conversion (OTEC), fixed offshore wind, and floating offshore wind.

Name: Belwind
Round/Category: Concession identified through decree of May 2004
Comments: Depth range for whole concession area is 15-37m  Revenues via Renewable Energy Certificate sold to Elia for 20 years at €107/MWh
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Apr 2018: J/U WIND was on site supporting turbine maintenance work.
Comments_A: 55 individual lengths of 33 kV cables

Name: Belwind Alstom Haliade Demonstration
Comments: The turbine was installed within the extent of Belwind 2's location. It was the largest offshore wind turbine installed in sea waters at the time and had a 15% better yield than previous existing offshore wind turbines. This increased efficiency could supply power to the equivalent of around 5,000 households.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 30 Oct 2014: Jan De Nul's vessel Simon Stevin completed the installation of the cable from the Haliade turbine to the substation. The scope involved 1,952m of array cable, CPU installation, post-trenching and scour protection.
Foundation Comments: OWEC Quattro jacket.  61m high  Weight of turbine and jacket = 1500t.
GridConnection Point: The turbine connects to Belwind 1's substation
ExportCableComments: The turbine connects to Belwind Phase 1 Substation.

Name: Nobelwind
Round/Category: Concession identified through decree of May 2004
Comments: Area concession granted in June 2007.   Permit granted in February 2008.  Project to receive revenues under the previous subsidy regime of fixed tariffs.  Revenues via Renewable Energy Certificate sold to Elia for 20 years at €95.25/MWh on top of the wholesale electricity price.  Despite reaching financial close after the deadline for the new LCOE mechanism at a CfD of €138/MWh, the project qualifies under the old certificate mechanism because it is part of the original Belwind concession that has already reached financial close.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 24 May 2017: Inauguration of the Nobelwind project took place, celebrating successful deployment of the 50 V112-3.3MW turbines.
Owners: Meewind,Parkwind NV,Sumitomo Corporation (????) Europe Holding Limited
Foundation Comments: Nobelwind will be using a bolted connection instead of the normal grouted connection. The main advantages are they are easier to model and analyse as well as certification being more straightforward.  Monopile weight 800t, length 76.4m and 6.8 diameter.
LandingPoint: Will be connected to the Northwind project (220KV) with additional redundancy coupling to Belwind 1 at 33kV.
ExportCableComments: The export cable will connect to Northwind's OHVS, then to Zeebruge/Stevin. The length refers to the cable from Nobelwind OHVS to Northwind OHVS. Nobelwind does also have a 700m  33kV redudency cable to BelWind OHVS

Name: Norther
Round/Category: Concession identified through decree of May 2004
Comments: Norther decided not to connect to the Belgium Offshore Grid and is creating their own link back to shore.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Feb 2019: Installation of the MHI Vestas V164-8.0MW turbines is expected to begin. Installation activities for the Norther project are expected to complete by the end of Q2 2019 according to an indicative timetable.
Owners: Eneco Wind B.V,Elicio nv (formerly Electrawinds NV),Diamond Generating Europe Limited
Foundation Comments: Monopile weights are expected to vary between 670-963 tons with a diameter of 7.2-7.6 metres, dependent on the individual WTG location. The average weight and diameter is 795 tons and 7.4 metres, respectively.
ExportCableComments: Norther will connect straight to shore via its own export cable.

Name: Northwester 2
Round/Category: Concession identified through decree of May 2004
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Jan 2019: Jack-up vessel Vole au Vent has started construction work on Northwester 2 in Belgium. The vessel has been booked to install the foundations and transition pieces on the 219MW project.
Foundation Comments: The monopiles have a diameter of up to 8m, a length of up to 82m, and a weight of up to app. 1000 tonnes. The transition pieces have a diameter of up to 6.8m, a length of app. 20m, and a weight of 189 tonnes.
ExportCableComments: Export cable will connect Northwester 2 to Elia's Offshore Switch Yard (OSY), connected to Modular Offshore Grid (MOG). The cable will have state of the art XLPE insulation, and will be supplied by Nexans in one length. It will be manufactured at Halden, Norway.
Comments_A: 66kV expected

Name: Northwind
OtherNames: Eldepasco, Zone 2 and Bank Zonder Naam
Round/Category: Concession identified through decree of May 2004
Comments: Monopile foundations were used following results of ground survey.   Area concession was granted in June 2006. The Belwind 2 project will connect to Northwind before connecting direct to shore.    Zeeland Seaports was acting as loadport for the Northwind (April 2013)
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 30 Jun 2014: The turbine installation was completed in May and a report stated that the project was completed at the end of June.
Owners: Aspiravi Holding NV,Parkwind NV,Sumitomo Corporation (????) Europe Holding Limited
Turbine Description: V112-3.0 MW Offshore (MHI Vestas Offshore Wind)
Foundation Comments: The monopiles have a diameter of 5.2m.
ExportCableComments: Diameter of 28 cm and a weight of 120 kg/m

Name: Poseidon P60 - Mermaid
Comments: Poseidon 60 is a hybrid wind wave device, featuring a 2-2.3MW wind turbine and a 600kW wave energy converter.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Dec 2018: Floating Power Plant A/S are currently targeting deployment of a hybrid P60 device in the Mermaid zone during 2018.
Foundation Comments: P60 unit

Name: Post-2020 Tender(s)
Comments: According to the Principle Memorandum approved by the Council of Ministers in August 2018 two options are considered for the new offshore wind tender; a single 1.75 GW (221 km2 ) zone, which could vary upwards by 20% (on average 7.9 MW/km²) or two 700 MW zones (110 km2 , 7.9 MW/km²) which would be launched simultaneously. The tender process is anticipated to commence in 2022 with construction beginning in 2024.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Dec 2018: An Environmental Impact study for the new zone is scheduled for 2018/19 followed by preliminary site investigation studies such as metocean, environmental, geophysical and geotechnical studies in 2020 and 2021.

Name: Rentel
Round/Category: Concession identified through decree of May 2004
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 04 Jan 2019: The Rentel offshore wind farm is the fifth offshore wind farm in Belgium to enter full operations. The total installed capacity in Belgium is now 1.186GW..
Owners: Elicio Offshore (formerly Electrawinds Offshore NV),Rent-A-Port Energy n.v.,Otary RS N.V.,Aspiravi Offshore NV,Power@Sea NV,DEME NV,SRIW Environment,Socofe,Z-kracht
Foundation Comments: Foundation max weight 1250t average weight 1116thornsea, 8m diameter. Transition piece have height of 22m, a diameter of 6m (top) and 7m (bottom) and a total weight of 325kg
GridConnection Point: Direct to shore (Zeebrugge) in first instance then also via Modular Offshore Grid when available
ExportCableComments: 40km cable from Rentel Substation to Zeebrugge.  When the MOG is available Rentel will connect also via a 4.5km 220kV from Rentel Substation to the Modular Offshore Grid (MOG)

Name: Seamade (Mermaid)
Round/Category: Concession identified through decree of May 2004
Comments: Originally SEAL (C0 Power Holdco, Electrawinds, Nuon) and Blue4Power I (Electrabel) were in competition for this zone. During second tender area was contested by THV Mermaid and Northwester  II    Mermaid are planning to install Wave Energy Converters in the project area.  Between 20 - 61MW of WECs are planned.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 11 Dec 2018: Eneco has concluded a long-term power purchase agreement with the other shareholders regarding the supply of the energy.
Owners: Eneco Wind Belgium SA,Otary RS N.V.,Electrabel S.A.
Comments_A: Park will use either 66kV or 33kV cabling. 4-6 strings, 60MW per string for 66kV or 9-12 strings, 30MW per string for 33kV.

Name: Seamade (SeaStar)
Round/Category: Concession identified through decree of May 2004
Comments: Seastar (Power@Sea, Electrawinds) beat Nieuw project (Econcern) and Blue4Power II (Electrabel) for the concession of the wind farm.    Proposed in concession request was for a project of 246MW (41x 6MW) although this is likely to change as new technology enters the market.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 11 Dec 2018: Eneco has concluded a long-term power purchase agreement with the other shareholders regarding the supply of the energy.
Owners: Eneco Wind Belgium SA,Otary RS N.V.,Electrabel S.A.
Comments_A: 66kV expected

Name: Thornton Bank phase I
Round/Category: Concession identified through decree of May 2004
Comments: Authorisation for project layout in 2 blocks, ground survey finished in September 2004.  Prework ecological monitoring finished in June 2006.  Stated cost if for the first phase only.    The project was financed on a non-recourse basis in May 2007: a Term Loan (Senior Facility) provided 90,286,340 EUR, Contingent Facility (Senior Facility) 11,200,000 EUR and Mezzanine Facility 20,000,000 EUR. Senior facilities were provided by Dexia Bank Belgium, Dexia Crédit Local, Société Générale, Rabobank and KBC while Mezzanine was provided by Rabobank only.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 12 Mar 2018: Heavy lift vessel Neptune carried out maintenance work on the site.
Owners: Socofe,DEME NV,Nuhma,EDF Energies Nouvelles Group,Innogy SE,Societe Regionale d'Investissement de Wallonie,Marguerite Fund

Name: Thornton Bank phase II
Round/Category: Concession identified through decree of May 2004
Comments: Phase 2 comprises 6 turbines in Area A (SW Part) and 24 turbines in Area B (NE Part)    Phases 2 and 3 share one export cable and one offshore substation.    The developer, C-Power, has 950EUR loan to finance this phase of the project.  Eneco has announced it will purchase half of all the electricity generated from the project.   The project cost reflects all 3 phases and includes electrical connections.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 26 Oct 2017: Maintenance work was carried out on turbine A5 by SEA CHALLENGER.
Owners: DEME NV,EDF Energies Nouvelles Group,Socofe,Nuhma,Innogy SE,Societe Regionale d'Investissement de Wallonie,Marguerite Fund
Foundation Comments: The 50 metre tall jacket foundations weigh approximately 550 tonnes each.
ExportCableComments: 3-phase 150kV submarine cable. Thornton Bank Phase II and III share one export cable and substation.

Name: Thornton Bank phase III
Round/Category: Concession identified through decree of May 2004
Comments: Phase 3 comprises 18 turbines in Area A only (SW Part)     Phases 2 and 3 share one export cable and one offshore substation.   The project cost reflects all 3 phases.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 05 Sep 2016: C-Power announced they will be partnering with Sirris/OWI-Lab and Vrije Universiteit Brussel to monitor the foundation structures at the wind farm. This will enable C-Power to keep track of the ageing process and plan maintenance work in an informed way.
Owners: DEME NV,EDF Energies Nouvelles Group,Socofe,Nuhma,Innogy SE,Societe Regionale d'Investissement de Wallonie,Marguerite Fund
Foundation Comments: The 50 metre tall jacket foundations weigh approximately 550 tonnes each.
LandingPoint: Project Shares Phase II's Substation and cable
ExportCableComments: NOTE: Thornton Bank Phase II and III share one export cable and substation.

Name: Asa Branca - Pilot Project
Comments: Due to environmental issues, a floating island may have to be introduced instead of a land based port. Power purchase agreements will be made with large consumers of electricity on the private market (consisting of special consumers, traders and self-generation). The project is awaiting for the Federal Asset Secretariat to sign the usage aggreement.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 23 Sep 2011: Eolica and Offshore Wind Power Systems Texas signed a MoU that gives the two companies one year to sign a contract for foundation use. This MoU was not fulfilled within that year.
Foundation Comments: Sea Titan platforms (Offshore Wind Power Systems of Texas).

Name: Asa Branca 4+ - CEMAB 4+
Comments: Project to be implemented in phases (approx 400MW).
Foundation Comments: Sea Titan platforms (Offshore Wind Power Systems of Texas).

Name: Asa Branca I - CEMAB I
Comments: Due to environmental issues a floating island may have to be introduced instead of a land based port. The project waiting for the Federal Asset Secretariat to sign the usage agreement.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Dec 2018: Developer expects to receive approval by end of 2018.
Foundation Comments: Sea Titan platforms (Offshore Wind Power Systems of Texas).

Name: Asa Branca II - CEMAB II
Comments: Due to environmental issues a floating island may have to be introduced instead of a land based port. The project waiting for the Federal Asset Secretariat to sign the usage agreement.
Foundation Comments: Sea Titan platforms (Offshore Wind Power Systems of Texas).

Name: Asa Branca III - CEMAB III
Comments: Due to environmental issues a floating island may have to be introduced instead of a land based port. The project waiting for the Federal Asset Secretariat to sign the usage agreement.
Foundation Comments: Sea Titan platforms (Offshore Wind Power Systems of Texas).

Name: EOL Planta Piloto de Geração
Comments: The project will be located in the Ubarana field, 20km off the coast of the municipality of Guamaré. It will feature a 5MW turbine with 65m rotor diameter, a fixed foundation and a 1km sub-umbilical electric-optical cable which will connect to the Ubarana Platform 3 (PUB-3). A solar powered anemometric tower will also be installed 350m from the turbine to measure wind speed and direction, temperature, humidity, pressure and rainfall. The collected data will be sent via radio to PUB-3 and used to evaluate the performance of the turbine and survey wind potential.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 06 Dec 2018: Petrobras has announced plans to invest $417m in renewable energy development, according to its 2019-2023 Business Management Plan. Although this is a relatively small amount in comparison to the $84bn the company plans to invest overall, it is the first time offshore wind has been included in Petrobras’ official strategy. The report highlights offshore wind as one the company’s main areas for renewable energy expansion alongside solar and biofuels. Petrobras will continue to investigate offshore wind potential over the next decade.
ExportCableComments: A 1km sub-umbilical electric-optical cable will connect the turbine to the Ubarana Platform 3 (PUB-3).

Name: Caucaia
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 08 Mar 2017: Project has been listed as dormant, as no information has been released, for several years.
Owners: ENERCE (Enerce Energias Renováveis do Ceará) Ltda
Developers: ENERCE (Enerce Energias Renováveis do Ceará) Ltda

Name: Pecem
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 08 Mar 2017: Project has been listed as dormant, as no information has been released, for several years.
Owners: ENERCE (Enerce Energias Renováveis do Ceará) Ltda
Developers: ENERCE (Enerce Energias Renováveis do Ceará) Ltda

Name: Cedar Spring
Comments: The capacity and number of turbines reflects the potential total after a two phase development. Phase 1 consists of 5 turbines with a 10MW capacity and phase 2 consisting of an extra 50 turbines with an extra 100MW. In total over the 2 phases the number of turbines will be 55 and the capacity will be 110MW.    Original plans were to start construction in 2012.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 22 Dec 2016: Ontario Government has announced it is to keep the moratorium on offshore wind development in effect until all the potential impacts are fully understood. The environment ministry said two recently completed studies for the government on noise and environmental issues show more research is needed, and that the province will monitor the Icebreaker project Ohio is allowing in Lake Erie.

Name: Kingsville Extension
Comments: Extension to earlier proposed pilot applications, see Kingsville Pilot. They are three projects with a pilot and an extension and 10 that will have 2 phases. Although if any get permission, they will work in the same manner. Namely, a 1st phase of 5 turbines then a 2nd phase of 50 turbines.    Original plans were to start construction in 2012.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 22 Dec 2016: Ontario Government has announced it is to keep the moratorium on offshore wind development in effect until all the potential impacts are fully understood. The environment ministry said two recently completed studies for the government on noise and environmental issues show more research is needed, and that the province will monitor the Icebreaker project Ohio is allowing in Lake Erie.

Name: Kingsville Pilot
Comments: Other turbines expected to be installed after initial stage complete. The extension has been proposed see Kingsville Extension. Of the 13 wind farms proposed by SouthPoint, 3 are pilots and extensions and 10 are 2 phase projects. Although if any get permission, they will work in the same manner. Namely, a 1st phase of 5 turbines then a 2nd phase of 50 turbines.    SouthPoint Wind has since issued a $1.2-billion lawsuit against the provincial government for issuing a moratorium on offshore wind farms.   Claim is due to the fact that the Ministry of Natural Resources arbitrarily cancelled all applications for offshore wind development and revoked SouthPoint Wind’s Applicant of Record status, leaving it with no certainty as to where its projects could be located and as a result of such uncertainty, previous site specific environmental studies and reports completed at great expense to SouthPoint were rendered useless because they related to tracts of land for which SPW no longer held Applicant of Record status, resulting in significant financial hardship to the Plaintiff.  Developer would also be required to reaply for future feed-in-taffiff programs    Original plans were to start construction in 2011.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 22 Dec 2016: Ontario Government has announced it is to keep the moratorium on offshore wind development in effect until all the potential impacts are fully understood. The environment ministry said two recently completed studies for the government on noise and environmental issues show more research is needed, and that the province will monitor the Icebreaker project Ohio is allowing in Lake Erie.

Name: Burgeo Banks
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 25 Feb 2016: Beothuk has proposed five projects, totalling more than 4000MW -  St. George’s Bay, Burgeo Banks, Prince Edward Island, New Brunswick and Nova Scotia

Name: NaiKun - Haida Energy Field
Comments: The proposed site is a 100km2 area within the total 550km2 area covered by an Investigative licence.  The licence also includes two transmission corridors that would connect the NaiKun Wind Project to Haida Gwaii (currently off-grid and on diesel generation) and the mainland power grid, and includes the license of occupancy for the Met Mast.     Considered an attractive site: Annual wind speeds exceed 10.0 meters/second ,The wind is the strongest and most consistent in the fall and winter when electricity demand is the highest ; flat sedimentary seabed, relatively shallow waters, access to BC Hydro’s power grid, and its proximity to the potential for increasing electricity demand in the Northwest.     Potential for upto 2GW of development. According to the developers, if an Energy Purchase Agreement (EPA) is acquired, the project would take approximately three years for finalization of supplier agreements, financial close on debt and equity, and construction. Obtaining an EPA is subject to the overall energy requirements in B.C, in particular, the demand for electricity in the northwest.     Given its development status, construction could begin within two years of the award of an electricity purchase agreement.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 15 Oct 2018: Orsted and Naikun Wind Energy Group have decided not  to pursue their joint partnership , as Orsted wish to focus on their US East Coast portfolio. NaiKun is in discussion with alternative interested partners.

Name: Wolfe Island Shoals
Comments: Ontario is not proceeding with offshore wind projects  on the Great Lakes until further scientific research has been conducted on freshwater offshore wind farms.     Ontario Power Authority has agreed to buy the energy produced from the project.   The project must be complete within four years. Before construction starts, engineers must complete a wind study, environmental assessment & engineering designs. They need to acquire land rights from the Ministry of Natural Resources.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 15 Mar 2017: On September 27, 2016, the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) tribunal issued its Final Award. The Tribunal dismissed the majority of the Windstream's claims in their entirety, including with respect to Articles 1110 (Expropriation), 1102 (National Treatment) and 1103 (Most-Favoured-Nation Treatment). With respect to the claim alleging a breach of Article 1105 (Minimum Standard of Treatment), the Tribunal agreed with Canada that Ontario’s decision to adopt the moratorium for reasons of scientific uncertainty was not itself a breach of Article 1105. The Tribunal concluded, however, that the failure of the Government of Ontario to undertake the scientific work necessary to address this regulatory uncertainty did amount to a breach of Article 1105. The Tribunal awarded the Claimant $25,182,900 CAD in damages and $2,912,432 CAD in costs.  The Government of Ontario agreed to pay the Award and interest in full. Upon receipt of the funds from the Government of Ontario, the Government of Canada made payment to Windstream LLC on March 15, 2017, fully satisfying the Tribunal’s Award.

Name: Toronto Hydro Research Platform
Comments: The anemometer platform project was initiated to study the offshore wind resource in Lake Ontario. This research is crucial in understanding the offshore   wind resource for which no on-site data was previously available.     Actual winds monitored over the research period averaged 7.4 metres per   second windspeed at 90 metres height at the platform location 1.1 kilometres offshore.    Toronto Hydro was interested in installing a wind farm with up to 60 turbines located between Ajax and Leslie Street Spit if the testing made a case for wind power.

Name: CGN Pingtan Island 300MW offshore windfarm
Comments: The project is included in the 'National Offshore Wind Power Development and Construction Plan (2014-2016)' and, as a result, will be treated by NEA as approved. This means the developers will be responsible for the risks and shall implement all conditions for construciton. Once the sites are qualified to a certain extend they can report to local authorities for approval.   The project is divided into A, B and C three areas. According to the plan, there will be about 33 turbines in A with planned installed capacity 132 MW (4MW capacity for each turbine). There will 14 turbines in area B with installed capacity 56 MW. And there will be 28 turbines in C area with capacity 112 MW.   Distance from central point to shore for A area is about 3.7km, about 7.8km for B, and C area is about 2.4km.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Jan 2019: Tender call for manufacturing and installation of 41 monopile or high-rise pile cap turbine foundations for Zone A (33 turbines) and Zone C (8 turbines).

GridConnection Point: 750m N of Houlang Village, Suao Town, NW of Pingtan Island

Name: 2019 Tender

Name: 2021 Tender
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 29 Sep 2018: The Danish Energy Agency (DEA) has highlighted four potential offshore areas for investigation (totalling 3,200 km2) for the three 800MW projects to be tendered in 2019,2021 and 2023.  The four areas are located in a delimited area in the North Sea west of Jutland, Jammerbugt, Hesselø and Krieger’s Flak. As agreed in the Energy Agreement, all are at least 15 km from shore; the extent of the municipal opposition right. All areas except that to the north of Hesselø are located within the state area reserves for large offshore wind farms designated in 2012; the Hesselø area will need require a strategic environmental assessment if it is pursued.     The DEA has engaged COWI to screen the areas to identify those with the potential for the lowest bid price, and whether tendering should include single or multi-site bids. The site screening process is expected to be completed by year-end.

Name: 2023 Tender
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 29 Sep 2018: The Danish Energy Agency (DEA) has highlighted four potential offshore areas for investigation (totalling 3,200 km2) for the three 800MW projects to be tendered in 2019,2021 and 2023.  The four areas are located in a delimited area in the North Sea west of Jutland, Jammerbugt, Hesselø and Krieger’s Flak. As agreed in the Energy Agreement, all are at least 15 km from shore; the extent of the municipal opposition right. All areas except that to the north of Hesselø are located within the state area reserves for large offshore wind farms designated in 2012; the Hesselø area will need require a strategic environmental assessment if it is pursued.     The DEA has engaged COWI to screen the areas to identify those with the potential for the lowest bid price, and whether tendering should include single or multi-site bids. The site screening process is expected to be completed by year-end.

Name: Aflandshage
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 27 Sep 2018: The DEA opened a technology-neutral tender on 27th September, allowing onshore wind, solar PV and open-door offshore wind to submit bids by 26th November 2018. Of the 2018-19 DKK 842m (€113m) budget total, some DKK 254m (€34m, i.e. 30%) is allocated to this first round in 2018; the remaining DKK 588m (€79m) is expected to be tendered in Autumn 2019.     Tender conditions stipulate that successful projects will receive a 20-year ‘price premium’ subsidy from the date of grid connection in the form of a fixed premium paid on top of the market price for electricity received. The wholesale price of electricity in Denmark, as traded on the Nord Pool, averaged DKK 230/MWh (~€31/MWh) across the whole of 2017. There is a bid cap on the price premium of DKK0.13/kWh (€17.4/MWh).     The tender criteria also require projects to be at a late development stage before participating; tenderers must submit an adopted local development plan with their bid, including an approved EIA report, a construction licence and a declaration of support from the municipal board (if located up to 8 km from the coastline). The winner(s) will be required to build their own grid connection and connect turbines within four years of award.

ExportCableComments: A 28km 33kV export cable also goes from the offshore substation to the Island of Anholt. This cable was manufactured by Prysmian.

Name: Frederikshavn Offshore Wind Demo
Comments: The site was originally owned by Orsted and was then acquired by EDF in 2015 and European Energy in 2017.     In 2016 the project lost out to Nissum Bredning in the Danish Energy Agency's pilot project scheme to support new technology. EDF allowed the site permits to expire and the project fell dormant.     Following the acquisitiong in 2017, European Energy seeks to get the permits ‘up to date’. It will feature   two turbines with heights up to 200m and three with heights up to 265m located 4.5km offshore. European Energy is working towards submitting a new Environmental Impact Assessment in 2019 with construction and commissioning scheduled for 2021/2022.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 21 Dec 2018: Lars Christian Lilleholt, the Energy, Supply and Climate Minister gave  approval  for the developers to carry out preliminary studies at the planned test site located 4.5km offshore. In December, 20 out of 29 councillors from the Frederikshavn Municipality also voted in favour of the project and refused to use the municipal right of opposition.    European Energy stated that since acquiring the project in 2017 they are looking to get the permits ‘up to date’ and increase the turbine height compared to the original project design. In November European Energy decided to reduce the number of turbines from six to five and increase the distance from shore by 1km. The Frederikshavn Offshore Wind Farm will feature two turbines with heights up to 200m and three with heights up to 265m.
ExportCableComments: Cable length and number of cables has been estimated where it is not yet decided by the developer.
Comments_O: Assume one cable. Nearest candidate grid connection point chosen

Name: GE Renewable Energy - Høvsøre stand 7 (onshore)
Comments: New test stand announced 08/10/2018: awarded to GE Renewable Energy, turbine model not specified.

Name: Haliade 150-6MW - Østerild - stand 1 (onshore)
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 03 May 2016: Turbine fully operational.

Name: Horns Rev 1
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 30 Jan 2019: According to Vattenfall installation of a new transformer and other electrical components is underway and expected to be finished by late February. However, the turbines will then be energised individually and it will therefore be sometime before the wind farm is operational again. Additional improvements are also being done to ensure that the fault does not happen again.
Owners: Ørsted A/S (formerly DONG Energy AS),Vattenfall Europe Windkraft GmbH
Foundation Comments: The monopiles weigh approximately 72.3 tons with a 4.04m diamter; the transition pieces weigh 158.6 tons with a 4.2m diameter and 18m length.

Name: Horns Rev 2
Comments: Horns Rev 2 and  Rødsand 2 have test sites available within their borders.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 30 Jun 2017: DONG Energy and Vattenfall secured an agreement on the supply of emergency power for each other's wind farm in Horns Rev.
Foundation Comments: With a length of up to 40m and diameter of 4m, each monopile foundation weighed up to 200t.
Comments_A: Total of 91 array cables.  8km Connection with Horns Rev 3 being built to provide emergency back up incase of export cable failure.
Comments_O: 150kV, 1200mm2 Al laid in trefoil formation, buried up to 1.2m. cable screens cross-bonded. Cables were supplied by ABB.

Name: Horns Rev 3
Comments: The project location represents the most favourable 400MW of projects identified in the 2011 strategy documents. In March 2012, the government agreed to another 1GW of offshore power by 2020.    A draft of the prequalification was released in October 2013 it was stated that only 6 applications will be supported and that applicants must have had experience in project development and management of construction. The closing date for any comments on this was 23/10/2013.    At the beginning of May 2014, it was announced that the Danish Energy Agency (DEA) had prequalified four developers for the tender of the Horns Rev 3 site: Statoil, E.ON, Vattenfall and DONG Energy. Vattenfall proceeded to win the bid.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 21 Jan 2019: The final  V164-8.3 MW turbine was installed. Installation stated 19th July 2018. Work was completed using Fred. Olsen Windcarrier's jack-up vessel Brave Tern. The Port of Esbjerg was used as the project's installation and pre-assembly port.
Foundation Comments: Monopiles to be driven 25-39m into the seabed. Each monopile is 40-50m long with a diameter of 6.5 metres. Each weighs up to 610 tonnes and has a 32m transition piecce secured by bolted flange.
ExportCableComments: Burial depth will be dependent on area. 1m but between 3-5 closer to shore.  Diameter = 28cm  Weight = 94kg/m
Comments_A: Fiber optics range from 6-12.  8km Connection with Horns Rev 2 being built to provide emergency back up incase of export cable failure.

Name: Jammerland Bugt
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 27 Dec 2018: Update: Jammerland Bay Nearshore A/S submitted the Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) report to the Danish Energy Agency (DEA). A public consultation is underway and will run from 27th December 2018 until the 28th February 2019. If the EIA is approved the developer can apply for an establishment permit and then an electricity production license.     The project will have a max capacity of 240MW and feature between 34 and 60 3-7MW turbines with max height of 200m and 154m rotor diameter. Gravity based, suction bucket and monopile foundations are being considered for the project and transmission system designs range from 33-110kV.     Update: The Danish Energy Agency now expect the public consultation to start November/December 2018.    Public consultation of the EIA report was anticipated in Summer 2018 but appears delayed.
Comments_O: The cables will be 33-50 kV and it is anticipated that up to eight  cables will be required. Transormation is expected to take place from 33kV to 50-110 kV at turbine, which is closest to the land. Alternatively no transormation and power will come ashore at 33kV.

Name: Kriegers Flak
Comments: An early decision was made that 66KV cables would be too risky as the technology is not sufficiently rolled out. The array cables will be 33kv.    The project location represents the most favourable 600MW of projects identified in the government's 2011 offshore wind strategy documents.    Rotor diameter 113-164m. Hub height 81-107m. Total turbine height 137-189m.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 20 Dec 2018: Vattenfall achieved FID for the wind farm.     FID was originally expected in 2017 but was put back due to changes in Government timeframe.
Foundation Comments: Monopile weight estimated at 600t. The offshore substations will use gravity base foundations.
Installation Base: Rønne Havn chosen as the port of departure for the wind turbine components
GridConnection Point: Ishøj 400kV, DK and Baltic 2 OSS, DE
ExportCableComments: 44km x 2 from the substation platforms to Danish shore.  11km connecting the two platforms that is not included in the average export cable length.    Also 25km x 2 from Kriegers Flak to Baltic 2 as part of combined grid solution.    The original plan was to have the grid connection based on a DC system with a connection to Germany via the Danish and German offshore wind farms. This was abandoned because the cost of the converter station was more expensive than estimated. The transmission system will now be based on AC technology.
Comments_A: between 6-12 fiber optic cables.

Name: Lillebælt Syd (Lillegrund)
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Jan 2019: An 8 week public consultation on the EIA run in in 2019.
Foundation Comments: Foundations being considered are monopiles and gravity base.
LandingPoint: via  Sønderborg or west of Nordborg
Comments_A: If 4MW turbines are used will use 30km of 33kV array cables or if 8MW used will be 23km of 66kV array cables.

Name: Bornholm (Nearshore Tender Area)
Comments: As with open door projects, generators are to pay for the grid connection to shore. Costs of environmental and geotech studies, estimated at 10-15m kr will be initially borne by Energinet.dk through a network tariff.The costs for the preliminary investigations in the area won by the concessionaire will subsequently be refunded by the concessionaire.    The nearshore tender is seen as a way of increasing competition for site development in Denmark - the smaller scale and relatively easier construction environment should make sites more interesting for developers.  Constructors are obliged to offer 20% of projects to local citizens. Constructors who can demonstrate that at least 30% of the project is locally owned by enterprises and citizens will get a price supplement of DKK 0.01/kWh.    Total turbine height 135-220m.    Energinet.dk, who is responsible for conducting the preliminary surveys and the EIA, has made available their cost projection for this. The cost of the surveys at any site is to be paid by the concession winner of the site. Only the costs of those sites which will be used in this round, are to be paid.  The final costs will be published in the fall of 2015. Vesterhavet Syd cost projection for these activities is 23.3 mll DKK or 3.13 mill Euro.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 22 Dec 2016: Energi-, forsynings- og klima minister Lars Chr. Lilleholt has decided to maintain reservation on  the remaining Nearshore Tender sites, which were included in the 350 MW 2016 Tender.  Reservations will be maintained until there is  clarification of the need for additional  procurement of nearshore capacity.  Area reservations will mean that there can be no open door applications for the areas.  The areas will only be included in any tender of additional coastal wind farms if there is local support for a new tender in the area.  The decision relates specifically to the areas of Sejerøbugt, Smålandsfarvandet, Sæby and Bornholm.
Foundation Comments: Gravity or Monopile most likely
GridConnection Point: Connect directly to the existing 60 kV   substation “Rønne Syd” with a 33/60 kV transformer or directly with 60 kV cables.
ExportCableComments: Cable length and number of cables has been estimated where it is not yet decided by the developer.
Comments_O: Nearest candidate grid connection point chosen

Name: Mejlflak
Comments: Mejlflak did not participate in the nearshore bidding process held in 2015. Has no current route to market aside from Open Door which is not economically viable at present due to low energy prices.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Oct 2018: The Danish Energy Agency expect to receive an updated EIA from the developer in oct/nov 2018.
Foundation Comments: Monopile or Gravity-based.
Comments_A: 33kV and 66kV under consideration.
Comments_O: Nearest candidate grid connection point chosen

Name: Middelgrunden
Comments: DONG Energy installed the Middelgrunden (40MW) and Avedøre Holme (10.8MW), however subsequently divested 50% of the turbines in Middelgrunden and one of the three turbines on Avedøre Holme. No partnership exists on either of the parks and the turbines are operated independently.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 14 Nov 2018:  Hofor (Formally Københavns Energi) acquired Orsted's 50% stake (10 turbines) in the wind farm. The park was established in collaboration between Københavns Energi and Middelgrundens Vindmøllelaug. In 2003 Københavns Energi sold its 50% stake to Energie E2, which has been part of Orsted since 2006.    HOFOR will ensure green electricity production after this year. The wind farm is due to operational until 2025. Hofer stated that they then want to replace the turbines with more efficient models so that green electricity production can be continued.

Name: Nissum Bredning Vind
Comments: The Danish Energy Agency (DEA) believes that elements, such as Siemens' innovative gravity-jacket foundation concept, tested at Nissum Bredning Vind will bring significant savings in regards to both construction and operating costs. Siemens' SWT-7.0-154 turbines will be connected by 66kV cables, expected to become the industry standard, which will result in lower losses during transmission. Further material savings will be provided by the slender tower concept, where Siemens will implement a new lightweight turbine tower especially suited for jacket foundations.    Full list of 8 development, demonstration and test elements:   1) 0-series test of SWP-7.0-154 WTGs  2) Prototype type test of SWP Gravity Foundation  3) Prototype of Slender Tower Concept  4) Prototype test of cables in Pipe (CIP)  5) 66kV (72kV) cables and switchgear solution  6) Test of LIDAR power curve measurement  7) Synchronization of rotors - Visual appearance  8) Optimized use of sensors and limitation of loads through reduced output from the WTG
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 12 May 2018: Nissum Brednings Vindmøllelaug I / S and Jysk Energi hosted an event to celebrate commissioning of the wind farm.
Owners: Nissum Brednings Vindmøllelaug I/S,Jysk Energi A/S
Developers: Nissum Brednings Vindmøllelaug I/S,Jysk Energi A/S
Foundation Comments: Innovative gravity-jacket concept. 3 legged with 1100t concrete TP and ice cones. Pile through leg of jacket.
ExportCableComments: Cable length and number of cables has been estimated where it is not yet decided by the developer.
Comments_O: Nearest candidate grid connection point chosen

Name: Nordre Flint
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 27 Sep 2018: The DEA opened a technology-neutral tender on 27th September, allowing onshore wind, solar PV and open-door offshore wind to submit bids by 26th November 2018. Of the 2018-19 DKK 842m (€113m) budget total, some DKK 254m (€34m, i.e. 30%) is allocated to this first round in 2018; the remaining DKK 588m (€79m) is expected to be tendered in Autumn 2019.     Tender conditions stipulate that successful projects will receive a 20-year ‘price premium’ subsidy from the date of grid connection in the form of a fixed premium paid on top of the market price for electricity received. The wholesale price of electricity in Denmark, as traded on the Nord Pool, averaged DKK 230/MWh (~€31/MWh) across the whole of 2017. There is a bid cap on the price premium of DKK0.13/kWh (€17.4/MWh).     The tender criteria also require projects to be at a late development stage before participating; tenderers must submit an adopted local development plan with their bid, including an approved EIA report, a construction licence and a declaration of support from the municipal board (if located up to 8 km from the coastline). The winner(s) will be required to build their own grid connection and connect turbines within four years of award.

Name: Nysted
Comments: Also known as Rodsand     Has been operational for a decade with a recorded 98% uptime.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Dec 2013: During 2013 Nysted produced 532,869MWh, or the equivalent of 3230 full load hours.
Owners: PensionDanmark,Ørsted A/S (formerly DONG Energy AS),Stadtwerke Lübeck GmbH

Name: Omø Syd
Comments: The planned wind farm has two proposed configurations: either 40x 8MW turbines (max height of 200m) or 80x 3MW turbines (max height of 150m). The first configuration is considered more likely due to technological advancements.     Reference wind speeds are approximately 9.5m/s at 120m hub height.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Oct 2018: The Danish Energy Agency 'expect to approve the EIA' during October 2018. Omø Syd also needs approval regarding the on-shore part of the project from the municipality of Slagelse. This approval will not be ready before summer 2019 according to the DEA.
Foundation Comments: Monopiles estimated.

Name: Østerild: Nationalt testcenter for store vindmøller(onshore)
Comments: National Test Centre for Large Wind Turbines  • 9 test stands for large prototype wind turbines(Spring 2017 - Danish Government approved two additional stands - maximum height 330m)    • 250 m is the maximum height to blade tip (Stand 1 only 210 m)  • 110 metres maximum blade length  • 220 metres maximum rotor diameter  • 38,000 m2 maximum roter area  • 16 MW is the maximum output per wind turbine  • 112 MW is the maximum combined power production
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 08 Oct 2018: Announcement of tender wins for the two new stands, awarded to Siemens Gamesa Renewable Energy (Stand 8) and Envision Energy (Stand 9)
Owners: DTU Wind Energy, Department of Wind Energy, Technical University of Denmark
Developers: DTU Wind Energy, Department of Wind Energy, Technical University of Denmark
Operators: DTU Wind Energy, Department of Wind Energy, Technical University of Denmark

Name: Poseidon P37
Comments: This floating platform has both offshore wind turbines and wave energy technology. The P37 is  a 1:3 scale demonstration model for the commercial P80. P37 is 37 meters wide, 25 metres long, 6 meters high (to deck) and weighs approximately 320 tons.    It is claimed that  P37 is the only wave/wind device in the world that has produced joint power to the grid in a real offshore environment. The project will now progress with the development of the commericial P80 device.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 28 Oct 2013: End of fourth and final test of P37. A total of 20 months of grid connected testing was carried out.
Foundation Comments: Poseidon 37 foundation is 37 meters wide, 25 metres long, 6 meters high (to deck) and weighs approximately 320 tons. It accommodates 3 turbines

Name: Reserved Area For Future Offshore Wind Development
Comments: Areas identified as being the most relevant for large offshore wind farms. The areas are now reserved and any applications made through the open door system will be rejected. Any projects inside this area will have to be won in a government-led tender.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 30 Nov 2018: Danish Energy Agency announce the further reservation of land in the Danish territorial sea for the state supply of offshore wind farms in connection with the Energy Agreement of 29 June 2018    The conciliators of the Energy Agreement of 29 June 2018 have decided to initiate a seawater analysis and a large-scale screening of the Danish territorial sea. The screening must include sites for up to 10 GW of offshore wind to ensure a comprehensive range of attractive sites for future offshore wind farms. The overall objective is to develop a comprehensive strategy for exploiting the Danish ocean wind potential.    In accordance with section 22 3, No. 1 of the Renewable Energy Promotion Act, the Energy, Supply and Climatologist may designate areas not already authorised, which are thus reserved for the state planning for offshore wind.

Name: Rødsand 2
Comments: Horns Rev 2 and Rødsand 2 have test sites available within their borders.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Dec 2013: During 2013 Rødsand 2 produced 738,512MWh, or the equivalent of 3568 full load hours.
Owners: E.ON Climate & Renewables GmbH,SEAS-NVE Energy Group
Foundation Comments: With a height of up to 16m and a footprint of 17 x 17m, each gravity-base foundation weighed approximately 1,600t.

Name: Rønland
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 14 Aug 2014: The four Siemens turbines have reached the significant milestone of having each generated 100 million kilowatt hours (kWh) of electricity since their commissioning in 2003. Contributing to this milestone is the long-running OEM service and maintenance agreement Siemens provides.
Owners: Thyborøn-Harboøre Vindmøllelaug I/S,Harboøre Møllelaug I/S,Vindenergi Aps
Developers: Harboøre Møllelaug I/S,Thyborøn-Harboøre Vindmøllelaug I/S,Vindenergi Aps
Operators: Vindenergi Aps,Harboøre Møllelaug I/S,Thyborøn-Harboøre Vindmøllelaug I/S
Foundation Comments: Piled

Name: Sæby (Nearshore Tender Area)
Comments: As with open door projects, generators are to pay for the grid connection to shore. Costs of environmental and geotech studies, estimated at 10-15m kr will be initially borne by Energinet.dk through a network tariff. The costs for the preliminary investigations in the area won by the concessionaire will subsequently be refunded by the concessionaire.    The nearshore tender is seen as a way of increasing competition for site development in Denmark - the smaller scale and relatively easier construction environment should make sites more interesting for developers.  Constructors are obliged to offer 20% of projects to local citizens. Constructors who can demonstrate that at least 30% of the project is locally owned by enterprises and citizens will get a price supplement of DKK 0.01/kWh.    Total turbine height 135-220m. Max number of turbines is 67 if the capacity is 200MW and the turbines are 3MW.    Energinet.dk, who is responsible for conducting the preliminary surveys and the EIA, has made available their cost projection for this. The cost of the surveys at any site is to be paid by the concession winner of the site. Only the costs of those sites which will be used in this round, are to be paid.  The final costs will be published in the fall of 2015. The cost projection for this project is 23.3 mill DKK or 3.13 mill Euro.    Update 2014: As part of the Growth Pack 2014 (Vækstpakke 2014) proposals the overall capacity for this nearshore round was reduced from 450MW to 350MW. There was also a cap put on future bids of 0.70DKK per kWh for 50,000 full load hours. Relevant offers above this cap will be subject to political acceptance. The 50MW pilot projects were unaffected.    Update March 2015: A multisite tender will be issued. This means that 6 areas will be offered for tender at the same time and that projects within these sites will be competing against each other. The concession owner shall build and operate the wind farm and the export cable to the grid connection point on the shore. A tenderer is allowed to submit more than 1 tender.     Furthermore,conditional tendering for 2 sites will be possible, i.e. a tenderer can submit offers for up to 350 MW conditional upon the tenderer being awarded concession for both sites.    The DEA will award the concession(s) to the tenderer(s) who has submitted the offer(s) which make(s) it possible to obtain establishment of the highest total capacity within the maximum limit of 350 MW at the lowest total average price. The license and authorisation for operations will be given for 25 years with the possibility of prolongation if allowed under applicable law. The concession agreement(s) offer(s) a fixed price/kWh for 50 000 full load hours (contract for difference) which makes a very predictable income. The fixed price will not be indexed.    Following pre-qualification the DEA will invite a maximum of 10 applicants.  In order to ensure that only genuine, professional tenderes submit tenders, the DEA is introducing a penalty for defective performance of 100 000 000 DKK (EUR ~13.5m). The required guarantee will be released when a capex of DKK 300m has been spent or the first kWh has been delivered.  At least 20% ownership shares must be made available to local citizens.  Full compensation forloss of local residential value where greater than 1 per cent must be paid.    The concession agreements are subject to i) the Danish Parliament adopting the necessary amendment to the RE Act to accept the winning price and ii) EU state aid clearance
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 22 Dec 2016: Energi-, forsynings- og klima minister Lars Chr. Lilleholt has decided to maintain reservation on  the remaining Nearshore Tender sites, which were included in the 350 MW 2016 Tender.  Reservations will be maintained until there is  clarification of the need for additional  procurement of nearshore capacity.  Area reservations will mean that there can be no open door applications for the areas.  The areas will only be included in any tender of additional coastal wind farms if there is local support for a new tender in the area.  The decision relates specifically to the areas of Sejerøbugt, Smålandsfarvandet, Sæby and Bornholm.
Foundation Comments: Monopile or gravity-base most likely.
GridConnection Point: Starbakke or Dybvad. One new onshore substation (60/33, 150/33 or 150/60 kV) close to the coastline can be needed at the sites: “Solsbæk” or “Haldbjerg”.
ExportCableComments: Up to 6 MVAC export cables depending on final project capacity, no offshore substation.
Comments_O: Nearest candidate grid connection point chosen

Name: Tunø Knob

Name: V164-9.5 MW - Østerild - stand 2 (onshore)
Comments: Stand currently testing Vestas V120-2.0MW (onshore model)
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 03 Nov 2017: MHI Vestas via an independent investigator has found the root cause to the turbine incident on 4th August 2017. The fire was caused by a 'faulty component that was damaged during installation within the prototype’s converter module, and that the procedure was unique to a prototype environment.' The root cause report concluded that the component, a standard industry component with a solid track record, was added solely as part of testing the prototype’s future upgrade to 9.5 MW. As such, none of MHI Vestas’ turbines currently in operation or under construction are at risk. MHI Vestas states that the release of the 9.5 MW turbine remains on schedule.

For Vesterhav Nord, the cable route will be approximately 4.9 kilometers long and 6.5 kilometers to Vesterhav Syd . Per Aarsleff A/S has the contract for the cabling and substations.

LandingPoint: Hvide Sande and Vejlby or Ferring
ExportCableComments: Up to 12 MVAC export cables (6 assumed here) depending on final project capacity, no offshore substation.

Name: Vindeby
Comments: This was the world's first offshore wind farm.   To protect against corrosion, the turbines were built with airtight towers and nacelles, and are cooled by heat exchanges.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 07 Sep 2017: Dismantling process was completed. Blades, nacelle and tower were dismantled and taken down by a mobile crane and placed on board a  jack-up vessel. The concrete foundations were broken down on site by hydraulic demolition shears, a hydraulic hammer and using milling tools. All wind turbine components and parts from the foundations were shipped to shore in Nyborg Harbour. Most components will be recycled and used for spare parts,  the blades will be reused in an innovative noise barrier concept and  part of a research project at DTU Risø. One turbine will be in an exhibition at the Danish Museum of Energy in Bjerringbro in Jutland.
ExportCableComments: 10 kV tri-phased. 50 Hz AC-cable

Name: DanTysk DK
Comments: The first stage was expected to consist of 80 turbines and a maximum capacity of 400MW.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 08 May 2015: Project will almost certainly not proceed. Consider project to have been cancelled as no mention of it has been made in press for several years
Owners: GEO (Gesellschaft für Energie und Oekologie) mbh

Name: Djursland (Nearshore Tender Area)
Comments: In March 2012 the government reiterated its commitment to several near shore planning projects (<20km).    In June 2012 a screening process identified 16 possible areas for development. The capacity for each area will not exceed 200MW therefore it is assumed that not all of the projects will be built. The screened locations have been subject to a Strategic Environmental Assessment (SEA) but an Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) will be required if the area goes ahead.

Name: European Energy GBF Enhanced Demo
Comments: European Energy GBF Enhanced Demo aims to focus on reducing the cost of construction of foundations and operation of offshore wind farms and looked to progress under the 50MW pilot subsidy scheme put forward by the Danish Energy Agency.    Nissum Bredning was announced winner of the Danish Energy Agency's pilot project scheme to support new technology, meaning that the GBF Enchanced Demo was not initially successful. Nissum Bredning accounted for 28MW of the total 50MW: it currently remains unclear whether the remaining 22MW will be tendered, although confirmation either way will arise soon according to direct communication with the Danish Energy Agency. If another award round is agreed, the GBF Enhanced Demo will be required to downsize to fit within the 50MW ceiling cap.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 18 Nov 2016: The Danish Government announced the abolishment of financing for the remaining pool of 22MW of experimental wind turbines that the project previously applied through.

Name: European Energy Life Cycle Improvements Demo

Nissum Bredning was announced winner of the Danish Energy Agency's pilot project scheme to support new technology, meaning that the Life Cycle Improvements Demo was not initially successful. Nissum Bredning accounted for 28MW of the total 50MW: it currently remains unclear whether the remaining 22MW will be tendered, although confirmation either way will arise soon according to direct communication with the Danish Energy Agency. If another award round is agreed, the Life Cycle Improvements Demo will be required to downsize to fit within the 50MW ceiling cap.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 18 Nov 2016: The Danish Government announced the abolishment of financing for the remaining pool of 22MW of experimental wind turbines that the project previously applied through.

Name: Sejerø Bugt (Nearshore Tender Area)
Comments: As with open door projects, generators are to pay for the grid connection to shore. Costs of environmental and geotech studies, estimated at 10-15m kr will be initially borne by Energinet.dk through a network tariff. The costs for the preliminary investigations in the area won by the concessionaire will subsequently be refunded by the concessionaire.    The nearshore tender is seen as a way of increasing competition for site development in Denmark - the smaller scale and relatively easier construction environment should make sites more interesting for developers.  Constructors are obliged to offer 20% of projects to local citizens. Constructors who can demonstrate that at least 30% of the project is locally owned by enterprises and citizens will get a price supplement of DKK 0.01/kWh.    Total turbine height 135-220m. Max number of turbines is 67 if the capacity is 200MW and the turbines are 3MW.    Energinet.dk, who is responsible for conducting the preliminary surveys and the EIA, has made available their cost projection for this. The cost of the surveys at any site is to be paid by the concession winner of the site. Only the costs of those sites which will be used in this round, are to be paid.  The final costs will be published in the fall of 2015. The cost projection for this project is 24.1 mill DKK or 3.24 mill Euro.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 22 Dec 2016: Energi-, forsynings- og klima minister Lars Chr. Lilleholt has decided to maintain reservation on  the remaining Nearshore Tender sites, which were included in the 350 MW 2016 Tender.  Reservations will be maintained until there is  clarification of the need for additional  procurement of nearshore capacity.  Area reservations will mean that there can be no open door applications for the areas.  The areas will only be included in any tender of additional coastal wind farms if there is local support for a new tender in the area.  The decision relates specifically to the areas of Sejerøbugt, Smålandsfarvandet, Sæby and Bornholm.
Foundation Comments: Monopiles estimated, although gravity-base foundations are also an option.
GridConnection Point: Two potential locations, one north of Kalundorg, the other further south. One new onshore substation (50/33, 132/33 or 132/50 kV) will be needed at the sites: “Ågerup” or “Røsnæs”
ExportCableComments: Up to 6 MVAC export cables depending on final project capacity, no offshore substation.
Comments_O: Nearest candidate grid connection point chosen

In December 2015, IKEA Finland signed a purchase agreement with OX2 for 13 wind turbines in Kemi, northern Finland. All the terms of the agreement have now been met and IKEA Finland has taken ownership.    OX2 will continue to manage the administration and operation of Ajos wind farm.

Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 30 Mar 2017: The project's current status - EIA for the project has been completed and currently links the project to the regional plan. The construction of the wind farm depends on the price of electricity, which needs to increase if project is to move forward.

Name: Kemin Ajoksen I
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 22 Jan 2016: OX2 and Empower PN Oy have signed an agreement on the dismantling of old wind turbines and the construction on the site of 13 new turbines.  The agreement consists of dismantling the old offshore and onshore infrastructure and the construction of new roads, lifting platforms, foundations, medium voltage network and communications network.  The design project is in progress and construction will be started in stages in spring. Main part of the construction works will be finalised by the end of 2016.

Comments: Suomen Hyötytuuli made a bid for EUR 20 million demo support from government, which was awarded to the project on the 26th November 2014.The Ministry of Employment and the Economy selected the plan as an experimental project for offshore wind power. However, the support must not exceed 18.5% of the realised acceptable costs of the project and, in addition, the project might be eligible for operating aid for the amount of electricity it will generate over a period of 12 years.    Project will use radar technology to detect approaching birds, if proximity of birds is too close, turbines can be stopped automatically.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Aug 2017: On Thursday 31st August Suomen Hyötytuuli Oy celebrated Tahkoluoto offshore wind farm’s take-over.

Name: InFLOW (INdustrialization setup of a FLoating Offshore Wind turbine)
OtherNames: Mistral, INdustrialization setup of a FLoating Offshore Wind Turbine
Comments: The aim of the project is to optimise the turbine prototype and conduct the project in regards to having a commercial phase in the future with a possible 26MW project and a larger 150MW project further in the future.    THE TWINFLOAT 2 MW has two vertical contra-rotating wind turbines with two straight blades each instead of a single turbine with three helical blades.    The INFLOW project will rely on the results of the onshore wind turbine prototype of the VERTIWIND project. The blades and the arm profiles of the turbine along with arm to blade and arm to mast connections will be optimised, based on the test feedback of VERTIWIND.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 27 Mar 2018: Floating wind turbine developer Nénuphar has been placed into liquidation, mainly due to failure of long time project partner Areva and delays in projects. Onshore prototype is to be dismantled. Offshore installation was expected in 2014 but was repeatedly delayed.
Developers: NENUPHAR SA,Fraunhofer Institute for Wind Energy and Energy Systems Technology (IWES),EDF Energies Nouvelles Group,Vicinay Cadenas S.A,Eiffage Construction Metallique SAS,DTU Wind Energy, Department of Wind Energy, Technical University of Denmark,Alstom Hydro Espana,DUCO Ltd,Vryhof Anchors NV,France Energies Marines

Name: Eoliennes Offshore du Calvados project
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 20 Jun 2018: The six french offshore wind projects which received tariffs in the region of  €200/MWh in 2012 and 2014 have received approval to progress by President Macron and Environment Minister Hulot with a new tariff of €150/MWh. This follows the dispute that the original tariffs were deemed too high compared to other projects around the world and factoring in technological advancements.    The four projects of 2012, are three from Eolien Maritime France (Fécamp, St-Nazaire and Courseulles-sur-Mer) and Ailes Marines SAS' St-Brieuc project, and the two projects awarded in 2014 of the Engie led consortium (Les Iles d'Yeu et Noirmoutier and Dieppe-Le Tréport).
Owners: EDF Energies Nouvelles Group,WPD offshore GmbH,Enbridge Inc.
Foundation Comments: According to 2014 plan, monopiles will be 6.7-7m diameter, 50-70m long and weigh 700-950t.
Comments_O: 225kV, it consists of two three-core cables with synthetic insulation. Nearest candidate grid connection point chosen

Name: EOLINK 1/10 scale prototype - THeoREM offshore test site
Comments: EOLINK concepts     - The conventional mast is replaced by four arms that improve the strength of the structure, reducing its weight and cost. This architecture makes it possible to install a larger rotor, for more electricity, on a smaller float, and therefore less expensive.    - Mobility of the float allows the wind turbine to rotate and orient itself naturally into the wind.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 19 Apr 2018: The Eolink 12MW FOWT 1/10 scale prototype was anchored and connected to the network at 8am on April 19, 2018, at the THeoREM research infrastructure  offshore test site.
Foundation Comments: EOLINK 7m x 6m

Name: EolMed - Ideol & Quadran Commercial Scale Floating Project
Comments: This project represents the post-2020 commercialisation goals of the EolMed project, following on from the pilot floating site awarded in July 2016.    The project will use the floating foundation that IDEOL has developed, which is compatible with existing turbines and competitive from 35 meters depth compared to conventional grounded foundations.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 12 Jan 2017: Creocean installed a measuring buoy and a current meter to collect site conditions at the site for a period of one year.
Foundation Comments: Ideol floating platform

Name: Floatgen Project
OtherNames: SEM-REV testing site at Le Croisic
Comments: FLOATGEN aims to demonstrate the feasibility of two different multi-megawatt integrated floating wind turbine systems in deep waters, never before applied to Southern European sea conditions, with the objective of assessing and comparing the solutions and the different combinations tested, thus generating knowledge to improve performance and allow future replication of the project results.  FLOATGEN was initiated by wind turbine manufacturers – Gamesa and ACCIONA Windpower – to demonstrate the technical and economic feasibility of two floating wind turbines in open sea conditions at depths over 40 m:    Demonstrator 1  2 MW turbine on a ring-shaped surface-floating platform (Gamesa, IDEOL and the Stuttgart Chair of Wind Energy at the University of Stuttgart)    Demonstrator 2(Cancelled 2014)  3 MW turbine on a OO Star Wind semi-submersible structure (ACCIONA Windpower, Navantia and Olav Olsen).
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 30 Oct 2018: Installation of array cable completed by Hydro Group, supported by French agent Wenex Equipment.
Owners: Gamesa Corporación Tecnológica S.A.,IDEOL,Universität Stuttgart,Fraunhofer Institute for Wind Energy and Energy Systems Technology (IWES),RSK Environment Ltd,Zabala Innovation Consulting, SA,École Centrale de Nantes
Foundation Comments: Damping Pool®  by Ideol.  Concrete foundation weights 5,000 ton.
Comments_O: Floatgen is connected to the French power grid via an underwater hub that allows up to three prototypes to be connected simultaneously. This hub is connected to an electrical station onshore via an 8Mw cable.

Name: Future Commercial Floating Tenders
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 26 Apr 2016: La ministre de l’environnement, de l’énergie et de la mer in the decree of 24 April 2016 on renewable energy development goals set installed capacity targets for marine energy (floating wind, tidal etc.) of 100MW by 31 December 2023. A further 200MW-2000 MW more will also have been  awarded, with the volume dependant on the experiences of the already awarded demonstration farms and prices.  Of the total 2GW max, 4C estimate that up to 1.5GW could be floating wind.

Name: Future Fixed-Bottom Tenders
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 26 Apr 2016: La ministre de l’environnement, de l’énergie et de la mer in the decree of 24 April 2016 on renewable energy development goals set installed capacity targets for fixed offshore wind of 500MW by 31st December 2018 and 3GW by 2023. Furthermore, depending on the availability of suitable sites and the experiences (notably costs) of the previous tenders, between 500MW to 6000MW of further project capacity will be awarded and in planning by 2023.

Name: L’éolien en mer région Dunkerque (troisième appel d’offres)
Comments: In contrast with previous French tenders, this tender will follow a "competitive dialogue" process, similar to the Danish model. Metocean and ground condition surveys will be performed by government institutes and available for scrutiny before submission of final tenders. This will allow developers to refine their offer as further information is released.    Furthermore, the winning bidder will obtain a site which already comes with a  "concession d’occupation du domaine public maritime", i.e. a build permit, thereby reducing the legislative hurdles in development.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 18 Jan 2019: Moulins de Flandre, the consortium of industrialists Deme, Quadran Energies Marines and Shell, candidate in the framework of the procedure of competitive dialogue for the realization of the Dunkirk's future offshore wind farm, signed an agreement with crowdfunding platform Enerfip. A crowdfunding campaign will be launched if Moulin de Flandre is successful in its bid.
Owners: Ministère de l'Environnement, de l'Énergie et de la Mer

As part of the APPEAL project, several measurement campaigns are planned in 2018 and 2019 on the Groix and Belle-Île site.
Owners: CGN Europe Energy,EOLFI,Meridiam SAS,Caisse des dépôts et consignations

Name: Les éoliennes flottantes du Golfe du Lion
OtherNames: Appel à projets - Fermes pilotes éoliennes flottantes Leucate
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 03 Jan 2019: Tender process started for supply and installation of 66 kV Submarine and Undergound Power Cables on 5th December 2018. The purpose of the contract notice is to achieve: An EPCI including the survey, design, engineering and compliance testing, procurement, manufacturing, supply, construction, installation, laying, burial and protection, completion, on-site testing, pre-commissioning, trial operation, spares provision and other services.    Estimated quantities and associated works for cable supply and installation:  — 3 inter-array (dynamic) power cables (3 km in total) and associated equipments and services,  — 1 submarine (static and dynamic) export cable (18,5 km) and associated equipments and services,  — 1 underground export cable (3,3 km) and associated equipment and services (mounting) but excluding the civil work and cable laying,  — 1 underground optical fiber (3,3 km) and associated equipments and services (mounting) but excluding the civil work and cable laying.  Associated equipments and services include, but are not limited to:  — landfall transition joint (including the joint pit),  — ancillaries equipments dedicated to underground export cable, including junction boxes,  — electrical cable termination and jointing works,  — ancillaries equipments dedicated to submarine export cable, especially its dynamic part, such as bend stiffener, buoyancy modules, etc.,  — power cable monitoring system.  All power cables and associated equipments detailed above shall be designed for a nominal voltage of 66 kV    Parties can bid in the tender until 3rd January 2019. The contract is expected to run from 01/04/2020 to 31/12/2025
Owners: Caisse des dépôts et consignations,EDP Renewables,Engie
Foundation Comments: Windfloat foundation with 3 catenary mooring and classic anchors.

Name: Projet éolien en mer de la Baie de Saint-Brieuc
Comments: The area being developed is 43% of the original scope of the tender as a consequence of using larger turbines and thereby reduces impacts on the most highly fished areas, limits visual impacts and reduces environmental damage.  Turbines will be laid out in 7 lines of 3 to 14 turbines with gaps of 1300m between lines and 1000m between turbines.  Cost of the grid connection expected to be €200m. The CAPEX cost of €2.5bn excludes the grid connection cost.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 15 Jan 2019: Contracts for foundation manufacture expected at the start of 2019; according to a local Spanish newspaper, Navantia and Windar are anticipated as front runners.
Owners: Iberdrola Renovables Energia, SA,eole RES,Caisse des dépôts et consignations
Foundation Comments: 4-piled jacket. A 30:34 ratio of driven piles (diameter 2m, depth 14m) and drill-drive-drill (diameter 2.5m, 45m) will be used.
Installation Base: Brest (submerged foundations parts and jacket assembly), Saint-Nazaire (visible part of foundation), Le Havre (turbine fabrication and pre-assembly).
GridConnection Point: Extension of the existing substation at Doberie
Comments_A: Each array cable will connect up to 9 wind turbines.  Two types of array cables:    Inter array: 70km x 130mm diameter  Collector to substation: 30km x 160mm diameter

Name: Adlergrund Nordkap
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 08 Jun 2016: The Federal Maritime and Hydrographic Agency (BSH) has received a planning application for project, however the BSH has expressed its intention to not grant any further authorisations until the 16th June 2018 under the extension and amendment of the latest development freeze. Only those projects granted approval according to Section 2 of the Marine Facilities Ordinance (SeeAnIV), or those that have held a hearing for the project's application according to the Marine Facilities Ordinance (SeeAnIV), and located in North Sea Cluster 1-8 or Baltic Sea Cluster 1-3 will be considered for the transitional tender rounds scheduled for 2017 and 2018. A project could also be a contender if it is located in the 12nm zone and has been awarded the final construction permit according to §4 of the Federal Pollution Control Act.   Therefore the project is not expected to progress in current form, as a central auctioning concept will be used to allocate projects in the future.

Name: Atlantis I
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 20 Apr 2017: Analyst view for 2018 auction:   Following on from the 2017 allocation, 2679MW of connections are available in the North Sea and 785MW in the Baltic. Between these two seas a maximum of 1610MW will be auctioned (1550 plus the remaining 60MW from the 2017 auction), with a carveout of 500MW reserved for Baltic Sea projects. Therefore 1110MW remains for the North Sea.    Around 5.5GW of projects are available to compete, although it is not expected that all Baltic Sea projects will do so under their current ownership. The key driver for zero-bids outlined by both winners in the 2017 auction are a late delivery (2024 or greater) and the associated technological advances this brings, and economies of scale. Site conditions (assumed to mean wind speed) was also mentioned by  DONG. Considering these three factors – 2024 or greater delivery, economies of scale, and wind resource, a simple analysis of the remaining North Sea Projects is possible.    It is assumed that He Dreiht will not bid in 2018 having already won with a significant bid, and Gode Wind 03 will not bid for further capacity in the auction due to a high density of 27.4MW/m2 following the first auction. The allocation of 900MW to He Dreiht means there is no longer any available capacity in Cluster 7 and therefore Vattenfall’s Global Tech 2 and EnBW’s OWP Albatros (not to be confused with ENBW’s Albatros also known as Hohe See Extension) must also be excluded. Vattenfall’s Atlantis I can technically bid for 14.4MW remaining in Cluster 6 but this is unlikely to be viable and is therefore excluded from consideration also.
Foundation Comments: Four-legged jacket structure 65m in height.
Comments_A: It is envisaged that the cables will be subject to a minimum burial depth of 1.5m.

A schedule for rescinding the sites and holding the future tenders has not yet been declared, therefore Bight Power I is expected to be dormant until further action is taken by the government.    Bight Power I may not apply for a grid connection during the 2017 tender because it has not held a non-public hearing; the project boundaries also overlap with Global Tech 2, adding further complications.
GridConnection Point: Candidate to connect to NOR-7-1 or NOR-7-2
