Name: Aicha
Comments: Blue H Technologies BV ceased trading in October 2012 and therefore this project has been deemed as cancelled.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 10 Oct 2012: blue H Technolgies cease trading.
Foundation Comments: SDP (Submerged Deepwater Platform)

Name: Turkish Offshore Wind Tender
Comments: The Turkish Goverment announced the countries first offshore wind tender in June 2018. The tender is for a capacity of 1.2GW, at $80/MWh and with a power purchase agreement for the first 50TWh produced.  The deadline for receipt of the tender bids is 23rd October 2018. The tender is most likely for a project sited in Saros, K?y?köy or Gelibolu.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 21 Nov 2018: The parties were interested in but none of them bid. Government postponed the project to an unknown date.

Name: NOVA (Novel Offshore Vertical Axis) Project
Comments: This entry reflects the long term goals of the NOVA project - to have a commercial offshore project established by 2020.
Developers: OTM Consulting Limited,QinetiQ,James Ingram & Associates,Centre for Environment, Fisheries & Aquaculture Science (CEFAS),Wind Power Ltd,Cranfield University,University of Strathclyde,University of Sheffield

Name: NOVA (Novel Offshore Vertical Axis) Project Demonstrator
Comments: The project looked at the feasibility of a novel offshore vertical axis turbine.     It examined the technical, economic and environmental feasibility of Wind Power’s Aerogenerator concept and highlighted the potential advantages over conventional turbines.    A full scale prototype is a long term aim of this project.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 15 Oct 2012: The blades for a 50KW prototype demonstrator were constructed in October.
Developers: OTM Consulting Limited,QinetiQ,James Ingram & Associates,Centre for Environment, Fisheries & Aquaculture Science (CEFAS),Wind Power Ltd,Cranfield University,University of Strathclyde,University of Sheffield

Name: Britannia 10MW Turbine Project
Comments: Initial testing to be carried out near to shore in the Blyth area. Turbine may then be placed on Dogger Bank
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Apr 2012: Estimated turbine installation date.

Name: PelaStar Demonstrator - Wave Hub
Comments: There will be a test period for 2 years then another 8 years of power production.  The ETI is prepared to invest £25m to create a demonstrator.  Cables have already been installed by the wave hub.    Stage 1 involves a competitive front end engineering study  Stage 2 involves final design, procurement, build and installation of  a single system  Stage 3 involves ongoing operation of the demonstrator for several years
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 19 May 2015: Pelastar pulled out of the Wave Hub demo due to an unresolved Ministry of Defence objection stopping Glosten obtaining investors.
ExportCableComments: Will connect to offshore hub

Name: London Array Phase 2
Comments: The capacity and the number of turbines have been calculated from the totals for the whole project. The original plans had a capacity of 370MW this was reduced to 240MW in order to mitigate for the Red Throated Diver population.    Approval to proceed with phase 2 is required from the Secretary of State following results of bird monitoring. In October 2012 results from bird surveys from Natural England and the RSPB have convinced the developers to submit an application for this project.    Consent is subject to the Grampian consent condition being lifted by DECC.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Mar 2017: Full commissioning date was estimated at Q1 2017 before it was cancelled.
Owners: E.ON Climate & Renewables UK Ltd,Masdar,Ørsted Power (UK) Limited
Foundation Comments: Monopile (not confirmed)
Comments_O: Estimated location of substation (close to true position)

Name: Navitus Bay Wind Park
Comments: The coastline is one of only eight worldwide awarded World Heritage Site status by Unesco.  The initial surveys suggest that there is a lot of unexploded ordnance. Geophysical surveys confirmed the presence of unexploded wartime bombs, however this is not expected to affect the project's timeline.   Export voltages 132, 150, 220 or 275kV.    Feb 2014 - after the final consultation the developers reduced the project boundary again in order to reduce the visual impact. The northernmost part of the area has been removed and therefore the capacity and the number of turbines has been reduced. Turbine heights 177-200m, rotor diameters 176-154m.    July 2014 - The Crown Estate invited all Round 3 developers to revise the terms of their agreement as the projects transition from zone appraisals to project development. This could mean that zone development agreements are replaced with project specific contractural agreements.    November 2014 - A smaller 630MW scheme or "Plan B" was submitted incase the original 970MW proposal fails. Plan B doesn't have to go through public consultation or have to prepare a report on Environmental Impacts. Plan B will be further out from shore.    January 2015 - PINS confirmed that the 630MW plan can go through the approval process with the original 970MW plan.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Jan 2019: Offshore construction for the Navitus Bay project could have started in 2018/2019 assuming the project was successful in securing a CfD in the second allocation Round.
Foundation Comments: Jacket, concrete gravity base or space frame structures.     Approximately half of the site (southern, further from shore) has been classed as a "Monopile Exclusion Zone" by the developer, meaning either jackets or gravity-based foundations will have to be used further from shore. The exclusion is due to unsuitable ground conditions, potential plume generation and dispersal modelling.
Installation Base: Yarmouth Harbour, Poole Harbour or Swange & Portland.
Ops and Maintenance: Poole Port, Portland Port or Yarmouth Harbour
LandingPoint: Taddiford Gap (between Barton on Sea and Milford on Sea)
ExportCableComments: Cable length and number of cables has been estimated where it is not yet decided by the developer. Cable will also be deployed bewteen the substations.
Comments_O: Possible 18 cables. 6 for first project and ducts for rest. Followed cable corridor.

Name: Argyll Array
Comments: Water Depth Mostly 35m.  Rotor diameter 108-175m.   Hub height 80-115m.   4 to 6 Offshore Substations.  If the AC/DC converter station is offshore, there will be 2 converters. If placed onshore (Tiree) there will only be 1 converter station. SPR is currently targeting an offshore converter as onshore is unlikely to get consent.  Up to 4 met masts.    The surveys have identified two key species that the project has the potential to impact; basking sharks and sea birds called Great Northern Divers that feed on the site in winter. Both species favour the shallow water around the Skerryvore Reef.    In order to minimise potential impacts on birds including the Great Northern Diver, SPR are considering a revision to the design of windfarm to exclude either part or all of the Skerryvore Reef area, reducing the overall size of the windfarm. Doing this would also avoid the area where basking sharks are present as well as avoiding Skerryvore Lighthouse.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Jan 2019: Year onshore construction was estimated to start. This was originally due in 2018 but the project was put into hiatus for one year before the project was cancelled.
ExportCableComments: Between 8-12 export cables between HVAC substations and converters depending on number of substations. Two cables per substation.  2 HVDC cables from converter(s) to mainland

Name: Atlantic Array Phase One
Comments: The number of turbines could be between 188 and 240 across all project phases.  Up to 4 offshore substations across all project phases.   Up to 8 export cables across all project phases.  Turbine height 180 to 220m LAT.  Hub height (maximum) 110 to 125m LAT.  Rotor diameter140 to 180m.  Up to 3 accommodation platforms across all phases.  Up to 5 met masts across all phases.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Oct 2018: First grid connection was supposed to be available for Atlantic Array (then a further 300MW by 31-Oct-19, 300MW by 31-Oct-20 and a final 300MW by 31-Oct-21). Originally the first grid connection was planned for two years earlier, 31-Oct-16  before the project was cancelled.
Foundation Comments: Jacket, Tripod, Gravity, Suction monopod or Floating
Comments_O: Up to 8 cables to come ashore.  Expect 6 single cables to be trenched for phase 1 and ducts for 12 more, phase 2 and 3

Name: Atlantic Array Phase Three
Comments: The number of turbines could be between 188 and 240 across all project phases.  Up to 4 offshore substations across all project phases.   Up to 8 export cables across all project phases.  Turbine height 180 to 220m LAT.  Hub height (maximum) 110 to 125m LAT.  Rotor diameter140 to 180m.  Up to 3 accommodation platforms across all phases.  Up to 5 met masts across all phases.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Oct 2018: First grid connection was supposed to be available for Atlantic Array (then a further 300MW by 31-Oct-19, 300MW by 31-Oct-20 and a final 300MW by 31-Oct-21). Originally the first grid connection was planned for two years earlier, 31-Oct-16  before the project was cancelled.
Foundation Comments: Jacket, Tripod, Gravity, Suction monopod or Floating

Comments: The number of turbines could be between 188 and 240 across all project phases.  Up to 4 offshore substations across all project phases.   Up to 8 export cables across all project phases. Name: Bell Rock
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Jan 2011: SSE npower Renewables & Fluor have pulled out of the project. The two companies took the decision following further assessment of existing and ongoing provision of radar services in the area for which mitigation has been examined and no solution found.

Name: Celtic Array North East Potential Development Area
Comments: Developer distance from shore and average length of the export cable are based on the whole zone.  This potential development area (PDA) will be developed following Rhiannon and will be divided into 2x500MW projects.  A proposal for the zone development is expected following detailed assessments of the potential impact on shipping, particularly services to the Isle of Man.    July 2014 The Crown Estate invited all Round 3 developers to revise the terms of their agreement as the projects transition from zone appraisals to project development. This could mean that zone development agreements are replaced with project specific contractural agreements.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Jan 2019: Estimated date for consent submission  before the project was cancelled.
Owners: Centrica Renewable Energy Limited,Ørsted A/S (formerly DONG Energy AS)

Name: Celtic Array South West Potential Development Area
Comments: July 2014 The Crown Estate invited all Round 3 developers to revise the terms of their agreement as the projects transition from zone appraisals to project development. This could mean that zone development agreements are replaced with project specific contractural agreements.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Apr 2017: Grid connection were planned to available on the two Celtic Array development areas including: 500MW 01-Apr-17, 500MW 01-Apr-18, 500MW 01-Apr-19, 1000MW 01-Apr-20, 500MW 01-Apr-21 before the project was cancelled.
Owners: Centrica Renewable Energy Limited,Ørsted A/S (formerly DONG Energy AS)

Name: Cirrus Shell Flat Array
Comments: Original 180MW (90x 2MW) submission aborted when developers found unknown large population of Common Scoters (sea duck). Following protracted negotiations with the developers, a revised proposal, covering a smaller footprint has been proposed, in an area that appears to be less important for feeding scoters. The level of interaction with the scoters has been drastically reduced by about 90%. The project was finally cancelled due to fears of impact on aviation safety and radar technology.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 13 Apr 2018: Both met masts have been removed.
Owners: CeltPower Ltd (JV between Scottish Power and Eurus),Ørsted Power (UK) Limited,Shell Wind Energy Ltd

Name: Cromer
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 07 Mar 2007: Project eventually aborted following ongoing engineering investigations due to challenging sea-bed conditions - the sub-sea strata did not have the load-bearing capacity required.

Name: Docking Shoal
Comments: The capacity, rotor diameter, hub height are maximum figures.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Jan 2015: Possible Year Start Construction.

Name: Dogger Bank - Teesside C

Name: First Flight Wind
Comments: This area was defined during a Strategic Environmental Assessment (SEA). Further consultation is being undertaken.    In light of the SEA’s findings, the draft ORESAP proposed targets of at least 600 MW offshore wind generating capacity be developed.    One or more HVAC substations. One or more export cables.    The project will require the following consents;  Marine Licence from the Northern Ireland Environment Agency as   required under Part 4 of the UK Marine and Coastal Access Act   2009.   Planning consent from DoE Planning Service under The Planning   (Northern Ireland) Order 1991 for all onshore works associated with   the project.   Consent from DETI under Article 39 of The Electricity (NI) Order   1992 for the construction and operation of generating stations.   A Licence to generate electricity for supply to the Northern Ireland   grid from the utility regulator under Article 10 of the Electricity   (Northern Ireland) Order 1992.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Jan 2019: Offshore construction is estimated to begin in 2019.
Owners: Ørsted Power (UK) Limited,RES Offshore,B9 Energy Offshore Developments
Foundation Comments: Monopile, Jacket, Suction Caisson, Gravity Base and hybrids under consideration.
GridConnection Point: Two preferred options are Ballynahinch and Castlereagh.
ExportCableComments: Cable length and number of cables has been estimated where it is not yet decided by the developer.
Comments_A: In extreme cases burial depth can be as high as 3m. Sections of the cables will be surface laid if soil conditions are hard and/or the risk of cable damage is very low.

Name: Northern Ireland Wind Resource Zone 1
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 15 Dec 2011: Not included in the first round of leasing for Northern Ireland. The Crown Estate did not offer this site at the same time as the other wind zone. This was because the area is deeper than current technology can cope with and a project could interfere with the Giant's Causeway. As technology improves the site may be reconsidered.

Name: Outer Solway Feasibility Study
Comments: DONG Energy was undertaking a feasibility study to consider the potential for a development site within this area of maximum size 280 MW generation capacity, which was likely to be a site area of around 60km2.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Jan 2013: On 20 July 2012 the Exclusivity Agreement has been extended to the date three months after publication of the Scottish Government's Post Adoption Statement, updating the sectoral plan for Offshore Wind Energy in Scottish Waters, in 2013.  DONG Energy Power (UK) Limited will undertake further feasibility work during this period. This work will not include any offshore surveys. On completion of the plan update by the Scottish Government, this may lead to the offer of an Agreement for Lease (AfL), but is subject to the findings of the updated Plan Strategic Environmental Assessment. The grant of an AfL would be for a site of no more than 61 km2 with a maximum capacity of no more than 280 MW.
Developers: Scottish Government - Offshore Wind Consultation,Ørsted Power (UK) Limited

Name: Rhiannon Wind Farm
OtherNames: Zone 9, Irish Sea South East Potential Development Area, Celtic Array Rhiannon
Comments: Multiple offshore HVAC stations.  Not yet determined whether HVDC offshore transmission will be incorporated. It is unlikely that HVDC will be used but it is considered the maximum worst case scenario. A HVAC transmission system would consist of up to 8 HVAC collector substations, AC array cables and up to 12 transmission cables. A HVDC transmission system would consist of up to 8 HVAC collector substations, up to 4 HVDC converter stations, AC array cables, HVAC cables from the HVAC collector stations to the HVDC converter stations and up to 12 transmission cables.   Number of met masts = 1  Turbine numbers 146 x 15MW to 440 x 4 or 5MW. Rotor diamter 140-265, hub height 115-178 and total tip height 185-310.    July 2014 The Crown Estate invited all Round 3 developers to revise the terms of their agreement as the projects transition from zone appraisals to project development. This could mean that zone development agreements are replaced with project specific contractural agreements.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Jul 2014: The developers, Centrica and DONG, and the Crown Estate have agreed that the developers will cease development on the entire zone and terminate their seabed rights. The assessment of the zone has shown challenging ground conditions which using current technology make the project economically unviable. There are no plans to re-offer the zone to the market.
Owners: Centrica Renewable Energy Limited,Ørsted A/S (formerly DONG Energy AS)
Foundation Comments: Various options under consideration including hybrids.
LandingPoint: Anglesey between Bull Bay and Port Lynas
ExportCableComments: 493km of export cabling will be used regardless of using either a HVAC system or a HVDC system. In a HVDC system there will be both HVAC export cabling and HVDC transmission cabling.
Comments_O: Land fall and grid connection point to be decided

Name: Aberdeen Offshore Wind Farm (EOWDC)
OtherNames: Aberdeen Bay, European Offshore Wind Deployment Centre - EOWDC
Comments: MHI Vestas specially designed the V164-8.4 MW and V164-8.8 MW turbines. The  turbines will be the first V164 models installed on a jacket foundation and utilising suction buckets and the 'short tower' option. The project will also be the first to validate 66kV technology.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 07 Jan 2019: During strong winds (67mph) the turbines completed six second rotations, reaching 200mph speeds.
Turbine Description: V164-8.0 MW (MHI Vestas Offshore Wind), MHI Vestas specially designed  9xV164-8.4 MW turbines and  2x V164-8.8 MW turbines.
Others: MHI Vestas specially designed  9xV164-8.4 MW turbines and  2x V164-8.8 MW turbines.
Foundation Comments: Three legged jacket with suction anchor foundations.   Jackets (inc buckets): footprint 77x37x37m, weight 1020-1240t.   Suction bucket anchors:diameter of 9.5 meters, height up to 15 meters and weight from 140 to 195 tons.
Installation Base: Pre-assembly of the turbines will take place in Esbjerg, Denmark. Jackets from Flushing (NL)
Comments_A: Ten array cables will connect the turbines.

Name: Barrow
Comments: CAPEX cost excludes OFTO cost: please see the relevant stakeholder entry for OFTO cost.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 08 Aug 2017: Dive operations at the offshore substation began on this date. Work was originally  scheduled for 2nd August but delayed due to bad weather conditions, Yorkshire Lady is the dive platform/support vessel and will be supported by CTV Katabatic. Work lasted 2 days and was completed on 10th August.
ExportCableComments: 132kV cross-linked 3 core polyethylene (XLPE)

Name: Beatrice
Comments: The draft decommissioning programme, released in September 2015, revealed a downsizing of the project to 588MW. Siemens will also implement two of its new Offshore Transformer Modules (OTMs) which will collect the generated electricity for transmission to shore by two export cables.The support structures for the OTMs will be identical to those used for the wind turbines.    According to the triton knoll ROI analysis by NEF, the investments in Beatrice Offshore Windfarm ltd. Is expected to total £2.6bn. Providing 18,100 jobs and an estimated additional £1.13bn to the UK GDP.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Feb 2019: Ofgem to complete the EPQ bidding and evaluation phase of the OFTO tender process in Q1 2019.
Owners: SSE Renewables (formerly Airtricity),Copenhagen Infrastructure Partners,Red Rock Power Limited
Foundation Comments: The 4-legged jackets measure between 68 and 81m high and weigh an average of around 1,000 to 1,150 tons.
Installation Base: Sassnitz, Nigg (construction and marshalling port and will store, pre-assemble and prepare the wind turbines ahead of installation offshore)
GridConnection Point: New substation at Blackhillock adjacent to existing substation.
ExportCableComments: Export cable corridor varies between 575-1054m in width. A 1.5km interconnector cable will connect the two Offshore Transformer Modules (OTMs).
Comments_A: 3-core 33kV armoured submarine cable consisting of:   - 42 type 1 (cross-sectional area of 630mm2)   - 48 type 2 (cross-sectional area of 400mm2)

Operators: Scottish and Southern Energy (SSE),Talisman Energy (UK) Ltd

Comments_A: 970 m between the turbines and 1920 m from WTG A to the platform.

Name: Blyth
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Dec 2018: Decommissioning of the project expected during 2018.
Developers: E.ON Climate & Renewables UK Ltd,AMEC Wind Energy Ltd,Nuon,Shell Wind Energy Ltd
ExportCableComments: Double Wire Armoured
Comments_A: Double Wire Armoured

Name: Dounreay Floating Offshore Wind Development Centre (DFOWDC)
Comments: Site is being developed to test prototype floating offshore wind technologies.    July 2015 - DBD SYSTEMS, LLC are to test their ECO TLP foundation and Floating Power Plant A/S are to test their hybrid wind & wave P80 system.    Area was identified as a potential location for a future test site in the Draft Regional Locational Guidance as part of the Sectoral Marine Plan for Offshore Wind Energy Development in Scotland.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Aug 2016: Marine Scotland has stated that the Dounreay Floating Offshore Wind  Development Centre (DFOWDC) has withdrawn from the consenting process. DFOWDC may not proceed without proper consent authorisation and therefore it is certain that the development has been cancelled.

Name: ECO TLP - (DFOWDC)
OtherNames: Dounreay Floating Offshore Wind Development Centre
Comments: The ECO TLP™ is a Tension Leg Platform design suitable for use in depths of up to 100m and constructed largely from concrete. The ECO TLP, the associated gravity anchor and installation process incorporate many features that contribute to lowering costs. The primary structural element would be concrete, produced using the “slip form” construction method. The platform and the gravity anchor would be constructed on a specially designed Construction/Deployment/Dry-dock (CDD) barge. Preliminary tests show that the foundation could support a 6MW turbine, in waters with wave heights of 15.24m and depths of 100m.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Aug 2016: Marine Scotland has stated that the Dounreay Floating Offshore Wind  Development Centre (DFOWDC) has withdrawn from the consenting process. DFOWDC may not proceed without proper consent authorisation and therefore ECO TLP will not be able to progress with its offshore demonstrator (unless a new project site is identified independent of the DFOWDC).
Developers: DBD SYSTEMS, LLC,MOCEAN OFFSHORE BV,Ewindfarm Inc
Foundation Comments: ECO TLP
GridConnection Point: Will connect via Dounreay Test Hub
LandingPoint: Will connect via Dounreay Test Hub

Name: Blyth Offshore Demonstrator Project - Array 2
OtherNames: NaREC Offshore Wind Demonstration Project, BOD
Comments: Test site owned by EDF for the testing of foundation technologies for their offshore wind farm projects.    The first stage of construction will focus on the development of ‘Array 2’ section of the wind farm (an arrangement of turbines closest to shore), requiring site investigations, design and procurement activities covering the installation of five turbines and the associated electrical cable which would connect to the electrical grid on shore.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 02 Oct 2018: Predictive maintenance provider signs 3-year contract with EDF Renewables at Blyth Offshore Demonstrator wind farm to monitor their largest operational wind turbines.
Foundation Comments: A hybrid of a steel reinforced concrete foundation, with a steel monopile.  Height: 60m  Base Diameter: 30m  On bottom weight: 15,000 tonnes
GridConnection Point: 33kV/66kV substation at Former Blyth Power Station (Northern Electric Distribution Limited (NEDL))
ExportCableComments: The 66kV cable is expected to have a diameter of 127mm and contingency for route planning could result in up to 5% of additional length on the export cable.
Comments_A: The 66kV cables are expected to have a diameter of 127mm and contingency for route planning could result in up to 10% of additional length across all array cables.
Comments_O: Connect to old Blyth Power Station

Name: Blyth Offshore Demonstrator Project - Array 3A & 4
Comments: Test site owned by EDF for the testing of foundation technologies for their offshore wind farm projects. Blyth Offshore Demonstrator Project may not exceed a total of 99.9MW, including Array 2, therefore Array 3A and 4 will not exceed 58.4MW at no more than ten turbine locations.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 04 Oct 2018: An amendment to the Marine Licence would likely be required for the additional arrays to proceed as consent conditions require construction to commence prior to October 2018.

Name: Burbo Bank
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 30 Mar 2018: MPI Adventure scheduled to arrive on site to carry out a component exchange at Turbine position BB32. Work expected to take 36 hours.
ExportCableComments: XLPE armoured 36kV 3-core AC cable
Comments_A: XLPE(cross-linked polyethylene) armoured 36kV 3-core AC cable

Name: Burbo Bank Extension
Comments: This is the first offshore wind farm project to be built using energy yield calculations based on wind resource data collected from a floating lidar.    Ofgem's Tender Round 4 will select an OFTO for Burbo Bank Extension's offshore transmission assets, valued in the region of £230.2 million. Tender Round 4 has been described as a 'bridge' between Round 3 and Round 5, only consisting of a single project. The Round will commence in April 2016, as initial documentation becomes available, anticipating a preferred supplier to be announced in March 2017.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 31 Dec 2018: NEC Energy Solutions will begin construction in May for the Carnegie Road battery storage project which is due to be operational by the end of 2018.
Foundation Comments: Foundations are between 400-600 tons.  TPs are 23m tall, 6.5m diameter and weigh 450t.
Comments_A: Will require eight array cable strings to connect the turbines to the offshore substation. 32 array cables.

Name: Dogger Bank - Creyke Beck A
Comments: The consent application submitted for Creyke Beck allows for up to 400 wind turbines in total, therefore currently 200 have been split across the two phases until further information is available.    July 2014 The Crown Estate invited all Round 3 developers to revise the terms of their agreement as the projects transition from zone appraisals to project development. This could mean that zone development agreements are replaced with project specific contractural agreements.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Nov 2018: BEIS published the Draft HRA document relating to the review of consents for the Southern North Sea cSAC/SCI (candidate Special Area of Conservation / Site of Community Importance) designation. This was originally due to be published mid-2018 but was delayed.    Context:   In January 2017 the Southern North Sea cSAC/SCI (candidate Special Area of Conservation / Site of Community Importance) was designated for the protection of harbour porpoise. When a new SAC is designated there is a statutory requirement for a review to be undertaken of certain projects, the consents for which were issued prior to the date of designation. As part of the review a Habitats Regulations Assessment (HRA) is required to determine any potential adverse effects of consented offshore wind farms on the Southern North Sea SCI/cSAC. The HRA is being undertaken by Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) and the Marine Management Organisation (MMO).    Eleven offshore wind farms were identified as meeting the criteria required by the regulations for a review of their consents to be undertaken (Dudgeon, Greater Gabbard, Galloper, Hornsea Project One, Hornsea Two, East Anglia One, Triton Knoll, Creyke Beck A and B, Teesside A and B).     Hornsea Project One, East Anglia One and Triton Knoll, East Anglia Three have already been subjected to a HRA that included an assessment of the potential impacts on the qualifying features of the Southern North Sea SCI. Hence the remaining projects included in the HRA assessment include Dudgeon, Greater Gabbard, Galloper, Creyke Beck A and B, Teesside B.    The conclusion of the draft HRA, published 1st November 2018,  is that the consented offshore wind farms considered will not have an adverse effect on the SCI/cSAC either alone or in combination with other plans and projects provided that the parameters of each farm as assessed by the HRA are not exceeded. It is proposed that each relevant project’s marine licence be modified by inserting a suitable pre-construction condition (requiring a Site Integrity Plan (SIP)). The effect of the SIP would be to limit the windfarms to the parameters that have been assessed by this draft HRA. If these parameters are exceeded, then further assessment would be required. In such a circumstance, the project could only proceed if the MMO, in consultation with relevant bodies, has satisfied itself that the site would not be adversely affected.     BEIS invites statutory nature conservation bodies, non-governmental organisations, offshore wind farm representatives and any other interested parties to comment on the draft HRA. The deadline for responses is 13th December 2018.
Owners: Equinor ASA (previously Statoil ASA),SSE Renewables (formerly Airtricity)
Foundation Comments: Considering monopole, multi-leg and gravity based options.
GridConnection Point: The converter station would be north of the A1079 between Beverley and Cottingham in the East Riding of Yorkshire. The cable route would then connect to the National Grid at the existing substation at Creyke Beck.
ExportCableComments: A total of 950 km of HVAC inter array cabling will connect the wind turbines to the offshore collector platforms. A further 320 km of HVAC inter-platform cables will connect the collector platforms to the converter platform. From the converter platform an estimated 420 km of HVDC export cable will connect Creyke Beck A to the transition bays at the onshore landfall.
Comments_O: 30km of HVDC connection and a further 2km once converted to HVAC.

Name: Northern Ireland Tidal Stream Area
Comments: This area was defined during a Strategic Environmental Assessment (SEA). Further consultation is being undertaken.    In light of the SEA’s findings, the draft ORESAP proposed targets of at least 600 MW offshore wind generating capacity be developed. 300MW will be allocated to this tidal area.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Jan 2017: Estimated Installation Start before the project was cancelled - Draft Offshore Renewable Energy Strategic Action Plan (ORESAP) 2009-2020 suggests projects could have been installed by 2020.
Developers: Department of Enterprise, Trade and Investment

Name: Dounreay Trì
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 24 Oct 2018: The project website states that the wind farm is 'on hold, but there is strong commitment of the project’s key suppliers to re-start the project and commissioning is planned latest Q1 2020.'    According to Hexicon 'the project is on hold and there is a strong commitment from key suppliers to re-start the project. However, commissioning in Q1 2020 is at this stage highly unlikely. We will try to re-start at the soonest possible, but this will need a bit of work, e.g. aligning a new investor.'    Earlier in 2018 the industry was lobbying for an extension to the RO deadline which has now lapsed, According to Hexicon 'no extension of the RO deadline has been achieved at this stage.'
Foundation Comments: Hexicon - Multi turbine floating structure:  Length: approx. 180m  Width: approx. 80m  Full load draught: approx. 15m
ExportCableComments: The export cable will be between 6-13.8km in length, depending on the final position of the platform within the site. The cable will weigh a maximum of 3.2 tonnes/km. As a worst case scenario, it is assumed that a maximum of 20% (2.8km) of cable may require protection, according to the Envrionmental Statement published to Marine Scotland.
Comments_A: A single inter-array cable will connect the two turbines and be built into the floating substructure.
Comments_O: The onshore cable will be buried to a depth of approximately 1m, subject to the ground conditions.

Name: Poseidon P80 - (DFOWDC)
OtherNames: Floating Power Plant, Dounreay Floating Offshore Wind Development Centre
Comments: The P80 device is based on 12 years of R&D activities including 2 years of offshore testing (grid connected) with the P37 research and demonstration platform, which has now completed. The P80 would measure 80m wide, and consist of a 2.6MW wave energy converter and a 5MW  wind turbine. It would be possible to install the P80 in water depths of 45m and greater.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Aug 2016: Marine Scotland has stated that the Dounreay Floating Offshore Wind  Development Centre (DFOWDC) has withdrawn from the consenting process. DFOWDC may not proceed without proper consent authorisation and therefore Poseidon P80 will not be able to progress with its offshore demonstrator (unless a new project site is identified independent of the DFOWDC).

Name: Dudgeon
Comments: Project will initially use a Service Operations Vessel (SOV) for O&M which will be in the field for a month at a time, with technicians working two weeks on and two off. The SOV will be needed in 2016, possibly earlier if used in construction. After four to five years Statoil will switch to a single fast 45 knot vessel.    Dudgeon will be part of Ofgem's Tender Round 5, expected to launch later in 2016, with regards to the sale of its offshore transmission assets once constructed.    Rune Rønvik stated at Offshore Wind Week 2016 that the project is on track to enforce 40% UK content.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 05 Nov 2018: TC Dudgeon OFTO plc (part of Transmission Capital Partners) has been granted the offshore transmission licence by ofgem under regulation 29(5) of the Tender Regulations (2015).    Ofgem published the final assessment costs to be paid to the Developer by the OFTO for the transmission assets. The final value was £297.9m.
Owners: Equinor ASA (previously Statoil ASA),Masdar,China Resources (Holdings) Company Limited.,China Resources (Holdings) Company Limited.
Foundation Comments: The monopiles will vary between 60-78m in length and weigh between 600-1000t. The monopile foundations have a diameter of 7.0-7.4m.
Comments_A: Both 185mm2 and 500mm2 cables.
Comments_O: 3 x 3 cables in trench - Dunham first choice, Necton second choice for substation

Name: Dudgeon Extension
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 04 Oct 2018: The Crown Estate has completed its assessment of received applications for extensions to offshore wind farms.  Subject to the outcome of a plan level Habitats Regulations Assessment, The Crown Estate intends to grant rights to extend the following offshore wind projects:  Sheringham Shoal offshore wind farm (extension of up to 317MW).  Dudgeon offshore wind farm (extension of up to 402MW).  Race Bank offshore wind farm (extension of up to 573MW).  Greater Gabbard offshore wind farm (extension of up to 504MW).  Galloper offshore wind farm (extension of up to 353MW).  Rampion offshore wind farm (extension of up to 400MW).  Gwynt y Môr offshore wind farm (extension of up to 576MW).    It is anticipated that the plan level Habitats Regulations Assessment will be completed by summer 2019.     The Crown Estate issued a notice on 7 February 2017 setting out the application criteria for offshore wind project extensions. A further notice was issued on 11 August 2017 amending one of the application eligibility criteria.    The deadline for submission of applications was 31 May 2018.

Name: East Anglia ONE
OtherNames: East Anglia Array, Zone 5, Norfolk, EA ONE
Comments: The EA zone has favourable conditions including relatively low water depths, convenient location near demand centres and good wind conditions .    The project supply chain plans references plans to use a small area (three to five turbine locations) of the EA1 Project as a demonstration site for turbines and foundations.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 03 Jan 2019: National Grid will provide the first 129MW grid connection to be available by January 2019.
Foundation Comments: Three legged jacket foundations.  Jacket weight: 850 tons.  Height: 62.6 m.  Footprint: 27 x 27 m.  Weight piles: 360 tons.
Installation Base: Great Yarmouth (Wind turbine pre-assembly and marshalling), BOW Terminal Vlissingen for foundations
LandingPoint: Between the Bawdsey Martello Tower and Bawdsey Manor
ExportCableComments: Two 220kV HVAC offshore export cables. The cables will be buried 50m apart, with a 250m outer protection on either side (550m corridor in total). Therefore there will be two trenches. There will also be two cables joining the offshore substations.
Comments_A: 102 array cables
Comments_O: Up to six 220kV HVAC underground cables. The six cables will be laid in two circuits of three cables, in two separate trenches.    Siemens will be providing 66kV array cables as part of their new option to provide their direct drive turbines, 66kV array cables, transformers and switchgear.

Name: East Anglia ONE North
Comments: It is estimated the maximum wind turbine tip height used would be 300m
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 12 Nov 2018: update: the Consultation Phas 3.5 was extended by a further two weeks and will conclude on 12th November.    Scottish Power Renewables (SPR) has added consultation phase (Phase 3.5) for investigating the potential of locating the onshore substations for project on the Sizewell Estate land (known as Broom Covert, Sizewell), as an alternative to the site north of Friston (known as Grove Wood, Friston). Phase 3.5 will run from 29th of September until 29th of October 2018.
Foundation Comments: Several foundation types are currently being considered for use, these are: 3 or 4-leg jackets on piles; 3 or 4-leg jackets on suction caissons; Gravity base structures; Suction caissons; and Monopiles.

Name: East Anglia THREE
OtherNames: East Anglia Array, Zone 5, Norfolk, EA THREE
Comments: There is the possibility of interconnector cables between different East Anglia projects. The export route to shore will need to carry the power a total of 190km, meaning standard HVAC technology will not be suitable. During October 2016, ScottishPower Renewables ruled out the possibility of conventional HVAC as additional onshore infrastructure (such as reactive compensation equipment) would be required, which carries an extensive footprint that is not desirable for East Anglia THREE. In December 2017 SP confirmed that they would be implementing HVDC technology.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 26 Feb 2018: Offshore Wind Consultants Limited (OWC) completed a contract for the provision of support covering a site investigation, preliminary foundation analysis, risk appraisal and turbine layout assessment. OWC carried out an assessment of the layout constraints and assisted with the development of the overall layout of the wind turbine generators while considering a number of variables including bathymetry, soil conditions, seabed mobility, foundation type and foundation installation.
Foundation Comments: A number of design are being considered some of those designs are jackets on piles (or suction buckets), tripods on piles ( or suction buckets), gravity based, suction caissons and monopiles.
LandingPoint: Bawdsey, Suffolk (same as East Anglia One, and same onshore cable route)
ExportCableComments: Up to four cables to connect the project to shore; up to four cables to connect to EA1, totalling around 200km and three cables to connect the offshore substations to each other totalling around 15km. Best estimates are shown in the design.

Name: East Anglia TWO
OtherNames: East Anglia Array, Zone 5, Norfolk, EA TWO
Comments: It is estimated the maximum wind turbine tip height used would be 300m
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 12 Nov 2018: update: the Consultation Phas 3.5 was extended by a further two weeks and will conclude on 12th November.    Scottish Power Renewables (SPR) is added consultation phase (Phase 3.5) for investigating the potential of locating the onshore substations for project on the Sizewell Estate land (known as Broom Covert, Sizewell), as an alternative to the site north of Friston (known as Grove Wood, Friston). Phase 3.5 will run from 29th of September until 29th of October 2018.
Foundation Comments: Several foundation types are currently being considered for use, these are: 3 or 4-leg jackets on piles; 3 or 4-leg jackets on suction caissons; Gravity base structures; Suction caissons; and Monopiles.

Name: Floating Power Plant - Dyfed Floating Energy Park
Comments: DP Energy and Floating Power Plant are developing sites in the south of Wales, north of Scotland and Ireland.     Floating Power Plant P80 platform can support a 5-8MW wind turbine plus a 2-3.6MW of wave energy converter.    Initial converter platform will have a total capacity of 7.6MW.      The projects will be developed in stages in order to mitigate the risks associated with the novel technology.    Consenting and Licensing in 2 stages  5 Units - 35MW  28 Units - 200MW    Construction planned in 3 stages  Single unit, for technology validation and certification  4 additional units, providing a commercial return  23 additional units, full scale commercial farm
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 12 May 2017: Announcement by DP Energy and Floating Power Plant that they have added a project in Ireland to be developed along with their  Welsh and Scottish projects.
Owners: Floating Power Plant A/S,DP Energy Ireland Ltd
Foundation Comments: Floating Power Plant P80  supports a 5-8MW turbine plus 2-3.6MW of wave power

Name: Floating Power Plant - Katanes Floating Energy Park - Array
Comments: DP Energy and Floating Power Plant are developing sites in the south of Wales, north of Scotland and Ireland.     Floating Power Plant hybrid demonstator platform will support a 7-8MW wind turbine plus up to a 3.6MW of wave energy converter.    The site will be developed in stages in order to mitigate the risks associated with the novel technology.    Consenting and Licensing in 2 stages  5 Units - 35MW  28 Units - 200MW    Construction planned in 3 stages  Single unit, for technology validation and certification  4 additional units, providing a commercial return  23 additional units, full scale commercial farm
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 22 Mar 2018: DP Energy and Floating Power Plant agree to push forward with plans for project.     In a comment on the joint decision with Floating Power Plant, Simon De Pietro, CEO DP Energy said:     ’We have undertaken a detailed analysis of the Katanes project located off Caithness and Sutherland in the north of Scotland and, having completed EIA screening, have decided to proceed to the next stage of this development. We consider Katanes to be a world-leading location for an early-stage development of this technology. This, together with the strengths of the local and national supply chain and the Scottish Government’s commitment to support the offshore energy sector, especially emerging technologies such as floating wind and wave, has led us to this decision. We look forward to engaging with stakeholders as our plans develop and are now working towards preparing an EIA Scoping Report for issue to the statutory authorities and for wider consultation. We are also evaluating the potential for further development off the north coast of Scotland and welcome the announcement by the Crown Estate Scotland that further offshore wind leasing is planned.’
Owners: Floating Power Plant A/S,DP Energy Ireland Ltd
Foundation Comments: Floating Power Plant wind and wave hybrid

Name: ForthWind Offshore Wind Demonstration Project Phase 1
OtherNames: 2B Energy Prototype, 2B Energy Test Site, 2B Energy Powerblock
Comments: The site can be used for demonstration for up to two offshore wind turbines.  The exclusivity agreement awarded by Crown Estates means that the proposal can go through the planning and consent phases.    2B turbines are two-bladed.    Application approved by Scottish Government for one turbine 20m from shore.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Jun 2018: The first two turbines of the ForthWind Offshore Wind Demonstration Project were expected to reach financial close during the first quarter of 2017 according to an indicative timetable but this has been delayed due to delays in achieving consent.     The project is now not able to be generating before expiry of the ROC in end-September 2018 and is therefore on hold. The developers along with RenewableUK, ORE Catapult, Kincardine Offshore Wind and Hexicon have applied for an extension to the ROC deadline.
Foundation Comments: The design is a jacket type which forms the tower as well as the foundation.
ExportCableComments: Estimated cable length.

Name: ForthWind Offshore Wind Demonstration Project Phase 2
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 01 Apr 2017: Marine Scotland (MS) submitted a Scoping Opinion in respect to the environmental statement.  The key points are:  - Although the development is relatively small scale it is located in a very important and sensitive area for seabirds and this means there are significant challenges to gaining consent.  - The cumulative visual impact of this development in combination with other nearby turbines is a key issue.  - These challenges mean that although the development is small in scale it will require proportionately more resources from the regulator and consultees to carry out the assessment .  - MS highlight these issues to make clear to the Developer that, although small scale, the development is high risk.  - MS emphasise that the developer will need to provide clear evidence to support statements with regard to environmental effects of the development.  - Transparent and effective communication with all stakeholders will help ensure that issues are identified early in the process. This will allow the best chance for difficult issues to be resolved although it must be recognised that MS do have significant concerns regarding the challenges which the forthcoming application will bring.
Foundation Comments: Floating Foudations at up to 3 locations -SATH SPM Platform and/or TrussFloat6 Platform  Piled jacket  Suction Bucket Jacket

Name: Galloper
Comments: Galloper Wind Farm will have a maximum installed capacity of 336MW and include 38 wind turbines in the northern array and 18 turbines in the southern array. No met mast is required at the development.    By April 2014, SSE and RWE's investments in development costs to date totalled £30 million. Galloper will be part of Ofgem's Tender Round 5, expected to launch later in 2016, with regards to the sale of its offshore transmission assets once constructed.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 22 Nov 2018: Ofgem has selected Diamond Transmission Partners as the preferred OFTO bidder. The initial estimated value of the transmission assets of £329.1 million is subject to Ofgem’s ongoing cost assessment process. Once the final value of the assets has been agreed by Ofgem, the preferred bidder will pay this amount to the developer, once the bidder’s OFTO licence has been granted to them by Ofgem. The reserve bidder for the project is Mari Energy Transmission. The reserve bidder may replace the preferred bidder if it fails to satisfy the preferred bidder matters, make the preferred bidder payment, or withdraws or is disqualified from the tender process.
Owners: Innogy Renewables UK,Green Investment Group (GIG),Siemens Financial Services,Sumitomo Corporation (????) Europe Holding Limited,ESB
Turbine Description: SWT-6.0-154 (Siemens), On 7th November 2017 innogy announced that working with Siemens Gamesa it has increased the power from of each turbine from 6MW to 6.3MW with an additional 17MW across the entire wind farm bring max capacity to 353MW.
Others: On 7th November 2017 innogy announced that working with Siemens Gamesa it has increased the power from of each turbine from 6MW to 6.3MW with an additional 17MW across the entire wind farm bring max capacity to 353MW.
Foundation Comments: Monopile foundation diameter: 7.5m  Monopile Length: Around 85m  Monopile Weight: Up to 1200 tonne
Installation Base: Great Yarmouth, Lowestoft (Offshore Coordination Base), Vlissingen and Rotterdam (Foundations)
ExportCableComments: It is anticipated that 4.7km of 132kV subsea export cable will be spare following installation and commissioning.
Comments_A: 56 array cables will link the turbines to the offshore substation platform in 12 array cable strings. Individual array cable lengths located completely within the northern and southern array areas vary from 950m to 6km; the three connecting cables linking the southern array directly to the offshore substation each measure 17km in length.

Name: Greater Gabbard
Comments: Project CAPEX cost derived from Fluor's end of year financial reports: 2008 saw an initial project cost of $1.8 billion, charges were then added to Fluor's accounts in 2010 ($343m), 2011 ($60m) and 2012 ($416m). Values were adjusted according to inflation and converted to GBP, bringing the April 2013 estimated CAPEX cost at around £1.883 billion.    The total estimated value of the Greater Gabbard Transmission Assets is £323,666,658 including financing and transaction costs (22nd November 2013); included in this value are the offshore substation, cables, onshore substation, connection costs, development, transaction costs and interest during construction.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 24 Jan 2019: Jack-up vessel Wind Server will be conducting major component exchanges at Greater Gabbard offshore windfarm. Site work is due to be completed by 31st February.
ExportCableComments: Spare export cable is stored in Harwich.  A 16km connects the Galloper offshore substation (not wind farm) to the Inner Gabbard offshore substation.
Comments_A: With 48 Single Mode 9/125/245µm fibres. Class 2 stranded conductors with longitudinal water blocking; Semi conductive extruded conductor screen; Semi-conductive core screen; Copper tape metallic screen. Armour package comprising single layer galvanised steel wire. 4.2mm Polyethylene outer sheath.  Spare cable stored with Offshore Marine Management and Harwich Dock Company.

Name: Gunfleet Sands
Comments: Dong submitted a contingency for emergency array cable repairs. The permission sought is for a period between 01/05/2014 and 01/07/2036 this will reduce the time waiting for permission to be granted.    Route to Market: Renewables Obligation 1.5 ROCs/MWh
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 15 Mar 2018: Ørsted   applied for a marine license to carry out additional corrosion monitoring activities during close out of the 5 year corrosion inspection plans . Work would involve short term water level monitoring, supported by correlating water quality measurements, in order to confirm that the internal water column remains both confined and oxygen depleted. This assumption of a stable water column is essential to establishing a corrosion map of the internal foundations, and will be supported by the data gained from the installation of water level and water quality logging equipment.
Owners: Ørsted Power (UK) Limited,Marubeni Corporation(??????),Development Bank of Japan,JERA Co., Inc.
Developers: Gunfleet Sands Ltd,Gunfleet Sands II Ltd
Comments_O: 132kV, 182MVA, buried to a depth of 1.2m. The cables have been pulled through the ducted section in approximately 400m lengths, in one trench.

Name: Gunfleet Sands 3 - Demonstration Project
Comments: The lease was issued to allow the testing of up to 2 next generation offshore wind turbines. The maximum capacity allowed was up to 20MW in total.    Dong Energy was forced to consider a dedicated export cable for its two-turbine Gunfleet 3 demonstration project off East Anglia due to the lack of capacity on existing wires.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 30 Jan 2015: DONG Energy submitted a pre-emptive application to the MMO that relates to works which would be undertaken should the inter array or the export cable.  This operational Marine Licence will only be used in case of an unexpected fault of the array and/or export cable at the Gunfleet Sands Offshore Wind Farm.    This licence is sought for the remaining operational lifetime of the Wind Farm (23 years) for the recovery and repair/replacement of up to three incidents.    The duration of an individual repair is likely to be as follows:   1. Onshore mobilisation: one month  2. Execution of repair work scope: one month  3. Cable reburial and survey: one month
Turbine Description: SWT-6.0-120 (Siemens), Also will fit a 154m rotor later on.
Others: Also will fit a 154m rotor later on.
Foundation Comments: Diameter: 4.650 - 5.350m  Length: 48.3m  Weight: up to 460 tonnordegrunde
GridConnection Point: Waterglade Retail Park, Clacton on Sea
ExportCableComments: DONG Energy was forced to consider a dedicated export cable for its two-turbine Gunfleet 3 demonstration project off East Anglia due to the lack of capacity on existing wires.

Comments: Hub height provided is the maximum height.    Between the 25th May and the 10th of August Seaway Heavy Lifting vessel Stanislav Yudin set a record for the rate of foundations installed. 80 monopiles and 32 transition pieces in 77 days.
Most Recent Lifecycle Event: 20 Oct 2018: Jack-up vessel WIND undertaking maintenance work at location F17E (53, 27.787"N, 003, 29.680"W), expected duration of 7 days. The vessel will require a 500m exclusion zone..
